description:
Places with 3.5 stars are always a hit or miss. I try to pay close attention to the reviews for 3.5 star places to see exactly what went wrong. But I thought Gold Mirror was a definite hit! After reading the other reviews, I think some of them might be outdated and a lot of them are about bad service--so that's something you can consider for yourself.

Now, I preface this by saying that if you're one of those people who's going to be like "I just spent 3 weeks in Naples and my palate has just become so Italian, you know, I'm such a refined food snob now!!!!" then you probably won't like this place and, pardon my French, but you should probably also get your head out of your ass.

But if you're looking for a somewhat fancy neighborhood place to get some good food, absolutely come here! The service was great, and our waitress seemed to be Italian herself. She was super friendly and prompt. The ambiance was pretty fancy; it seemed like one of those old school places that you'd take someone you like on a first date or something. Gold Mirror has a charming interior.

The food was great too! We had the minestrone and mushroom/pancetta soup and both were delicious. The lasagna was weirdly flat shaped but tasted delicious. The meat was tender and not at all like typical ground beef, and it was gooey and cheesy. We also had the pasta of the day, which today was some sort of seafood pasta that smelled and tasted amazing! We also shared the lemon butter salmon which was sooooo buttery and delightfully lemony. I loved every bite! For dessert, we ordered the tiramisu and the zabaglione. The tiramisu was good, and my boyfriend thought it was unique (he orders tiramisu wherever we go). I've never had zabaglione before, but it was basically like a boozy, fruity warm custard. It's VERY boozy but very delicious, if you're into that kind of thing :)

Overall, I'd definitely come back but probably only on special occasions because it is quite a bit expensive!
author: Claire C.

description:
I think you should really try this restaurant because it's my favorite Italian restaurant so far out of all of the Italian restaurants I have ever tried.Here are some reasons:
1 the people here are really nice.
2 the restaurant itself is very pretty.
3 The food there is very unique and yummy at the same time.
author: Keith M.

description:
I ride the train past this place every day but for some reason it's taken me a few years to try it out. Regret! This is an old school red sauce kind of place and it is perfect. Fresh not canned. Approachable not pretentious. Delicious not bland. I wake up in the middle of the night craving the lasagna. Just rock solid all around. I used to go all the way to the Castro to feed the need, now I just train it for 20 blocks.

Lunchtime parking not bad. Highly recommend the L train in the evening. Stop at 19th is one block away.
author: Matt J.

description: Have been here twice and each time it was very enjoyable.  The tortellini is excellent and that's what I had both times. The wait staff are very good and the place seems to have a big clientele.  I like the decor and don't think it needs an upgrade.  This is one of those fun restaurants that makes you feel like you are dining out for a special experience -- not a fancy schmancy over-the-top place that charges waaaay too much, but a place that has good food with little fuss!
author: Norah M.

description:
Excellent old school Italian with black bow tie waiters. I first came here shortly after I moved to the Bay Area in 1979????? Time flies so quickly. After a visit to Golden Gate Park, the De Young Museum, or perhaps returning from Marin County, this is a great stop. 

My friends had the cannelloni and veal piccata and both pronounced the dishes among the best versions they had ever had. The excellent veal piccata is floured and cooked in white wine and butter. Our appetizer, the garlic prawns were amazing. I thought at first they might be overcooked because they looked blackened, but they were perfect. My companions tried the daily specials, rack of lamb and chicken fettuccine. Again, everything was perfectly cooked and flavorful. I don't do desert but friends said tiramisu was a keeper.

Plan a leisurely meal as you won't get in and out in 20 minutes. The décor is dated and it is difficult to find parking. Still one of my favorites. I need to find more excuses to get into SF and dine here again.
author: David K.

description:
Seriously a diamond in the sunset/Parkside. My meals never disappoint here. Brought my cousins to enjoy a meal and it was absolutely delicious. 

We started with the roasted artichokes special and we could have ended there. Lol! These were heaven sent! See picture and if on menu do yourself a huge favor and get these! 

Three of us ordered the halibut and one chicken Milanese. All we're amazing. 

Attentive service and an overall wonderful evening. Money well spent and why we keep coming back!
author: Christine V.

description:
I've been here plenty of times and haven't had not one bad dish. Their veal picatta is literally the best in the city. Pasta with mushrooms and chicken is spot on, etc. The service is great great great. Owned by two brothers now (from the original fam), Dom & Roberto are wonderful and Dean at the bar is friendly and efficient...even the hostess(es) are fun. 

I travel from Twin Peaks so it's close. Parking is easy and I feel like family. While re-reading I don't want to give you the impression I'm giving them any pass, they're great and check out my other reviews over the past 10 years. Try Gold Mirror if you haven't and I'm sure you'll agree...esp. the Veal Picatta! Yum yum yum
author: Stephen S.

description: For what it is, it is as good as it gets. My S.O. had spaghetti and meatballs - He LOVED it, and he can be picky about his spaghetti. The service was really good, and the Bar was fantastic looking. Their selection of alcohol is pretty darn good. I had a Ruby Slipper, and I'm not complaining. It's pretty good bang for your buck, and the parking in the area isn't that difficult by San Francisco standards.  Overall, an enjoyable place to dine.
author: Maggie B.

description:
Thought the food was pretty good.  I had the veal saltimboca and a Caesar, both were good.  My guests had veal and salmon, both enjoyed their meals.  I love the way it was decorated for the holidays and the neon sign outside, real old world SF. 

I'd say a 4-4.5 place except the service was pretty bad.  Granted, it was crowded and all, that's fine, but, walking in and waiting at least 5 minutes for the hostess is inexcusable.   Waiting for water, waiting to order a drink, waiting to order, waiting for bread, waiting for food to arrive.  Just too much waiting, and, it wasn't because they didn't have enough people, it's just they didn't have enough people being efficient, this was evident. 

I'd still come back for the food and ambiance, but, if I need to wait to this extent again, the next time will be the last time. 

Ya feel me ??
author: Johnny L.

description: Came to dinner for my bfs grandmas 72nd birthday and had high hopes after reading some reviews but left disappointed. Service was friendly but the food lacked flavor. The food looked great at first, I had  the rib eye and asked for medium rare which was over cooked and the baked potato was not hot, but the veggies were good. Ended up getting cheesecake for dessert and took one bite and was done. Did not taste like cheesecake, rather have gone to the iron gate but that's what we get for trying new things.
author: Dominguez J.

description: Fantastic Italian food in old fashioned but cozy Italian decor. Came here to celebrate boyfriend's birthday for dinner and we loved every bite of all the dishes, including the free bread :) we had the calamari appetizer, lasagna (perfect amount of cheese and meat), and clam spaghetti dish (they give u so many clams!!!) Everything tastes homemade and fresh. Can't wait to come back.
author: Kat K.

description:
It's bad enough we are shoved into corner, but then waiter totally snubs us. Busboy brought water and bread pretty quick, but waiter didn't even bother greeting us before table next to us arrives and he greets them and takes their order. He then takes care of a reject salad from another table before he eventually comes to greet us which was basically "any questions?" and "Are you ready to order?" and then takes our order. He never even asked for our drink order. Then it turns out they are out of the only thing I wanted to eat, so I start looking at the menu. I ask him to go ahead and put the rest of the order in while I peruse the menu again and he says he has to put whole order in at once or else the kitchen will get confused. Really? Like you're a new restaurant? And haven't been in business forever? So instead of making my whole party wait for me to decide, including my elderly mother, I skipped on entree. Rude, unprofessional, intolerant waiter. Poor attitude. Cold service. Unapologetic. Poor reflection on a Restaurant that is supposed to be a neighborhood gem and SF institution. 

Now he won't give us water or food. Yes, I'm writing this review as I am sitting in the restaurant. Keeps me from thinking about how hungry I am. Table that came after us got dessert, leftovers packed up and their bill. We're just waiting....Hostess notices we haven't been served after 1.25 hours and goes to kitchen to bring us food with help from another server. Pastas clearly have been sitting around. There is dry crusty layer forming on tops. She says to be careful, plates are hot. Uh, barely warm. She does end up comping the two starters we had. She apologizes that they had huge party upstairs. Our jerk server makes excuses later saying he couldn't get our ticket in before big group, yet others who came in after us and ordered after us all got their food. Hmmm...
author: Carrie W.

description: Gone are the days when lunch specials included a choice of salad or cup of minestrone soup.  Cannelloni served with very rich cream tomato sauce and a few slices of warm bread. Veal filling quite tasty.  Old school neighborhood spot popular with old timers.
author: blaine s.

description:
Talk about an awesome neighborhood Italian place! :) 

We were recommended to try the chicken pasta which was not amazing, but the pasta was surely was ! 

The tortilini with white sauce was my favorite! It gave me a taste of italy you could say! Each bite as so soft and melted in your mouth! Additionally, you have to try the sweet bread! :) It was cooked extremely well and every bit as perfect tender!

At least 2/3 dishes where amazing :)
author: Khuyen D.

description: The food is superior. Priced reasonable. Parking difficult.  Service slow and indifferent. Clean and attractive. We'd go again.
author: Charles T.

description: Updating review, although the food is excellent the service is horrible.  The wait staff just have too many tables to cover resulting in horrible service.  If you do not mind waiting for slow service then you'll enjoy the meal.
author: Robert H.

description: The decor is dated but in a fun take your grandma down memory lane way.  The food was delicious with thin soft pasta sheets for the lasagna and cannelloni. Some of the best calamari we have ever had with great seasoning that didn't need a heavy batter, very tender not a single rubbery piece. Clam chowder wasn't bad but is not a reorder.
author: Angela S.

description:
This place is a straight-up purely awesome old skool San Francisco "real" restaurant. I love this place. It's full of neighborhood locals who have good reason to come here (and bring their families) because the food and service are THAT good. 

I don't suggest thathardcore foodies come here... mostly because you're jerks and will miss the point because they aren't playing the same game as the trendy places. 

I do suggest you come here if you want to have an awesome meal of exceptional comfort food surrounded by families who have come here once a week, or so, for decades. The restaurant staff and their customers obviously adore and respect one another and that, frankly, is pure magic. 

Highly recommended.
author: Jack D.

description:
I'm sorry, I didn't love it. 

2.5-3 stars. Everybody else liked their food. So that's good. 

The Ravioli shell was actually good in terms of taste, like I actually LOVED the shell but the filling was really tiny. 

The ratio was questionable. The pasta where there was no filling, the pasta was very extended and thin.. so it was like a 4x4 with a 1x1 filling ratio (I'm not even trying to guesstimate the actual size.. just ratio). Sauce was okay I think.. I can't remember the sauce. It was that forgettable same with the filling. 

The escargot wasn't bad, but honestly I haven't had that much experience with it. Boyfriend said it couldn't been crispier (wasn't crispy).

Service was okay, not bad. They were nice. Very hasty and messy server with the waters though, but no biggie.

Cute place though.
author: Lilian L.

description: This has always been a family fav. To night we went for a birthday celebration. Had the worst waiter. Come on guy a little friendliness goes a long way and not at the very end when you're fishing for a tip. Party of 6, drinks, apps., entrees and dessert, not a cheap dinner. He took away drinks before they were finished, not mine I would have karate chopped his arm.  Had to wait for bread too long. Couldn't bother to serve the hot plate without passing it by two people.  Birthday boys after dinner drink spilled, never offered to clean it up or get him another.  Not that busy he stood around a lot. Too bad food was good, may be time to hang it up. Most likely won't be back. Go to Joe's instead.
author: L O.

description:
Wow such a great experience.  
Pros: unbelievably tender calamari steaks, tortellini that was rich and flavorful (cream sauce) and an amazing veal dish. Service was the best.  Paulo was the best waiter I have had the pleasure of working with in a long time. 
Cons: the prosciutto appetizer was wrapped around almost frozen peaches.  The Caesar salad dressing had no taste at all. 
I would definitely recommend this place. Old school, neighborhood feel.  Best service around.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: We had a grand time, order the rib eye and the forest mushroom chicken.  We took the dessert home. We got here on a Wednesday night right when they opened, gets busy about an hour later.
author: Kevin L.

description: Went there today tried the osso bucco it was terrible had to send it back.tough and  had gristyle in it and to add  insult in to injury they wanted 36.00 for 1 piece  out of it all I have to say we had good waitress  she was italian.I wouldn't recommend this place to any one.won't be back.I've given this place 3 trys.each time not satisfied
author: Charles A.

description:
I had the prosciutto ravioli which was perfect  and my boyfriend had the lasagna. We had intended to share but enjoyed our own dishes too much to give up a bite. 

The service was very good. We weren't rushed though we only sat down an hour before closing and had a lovely experience. The homemade pasta is worth the price.
author: Briana I.

description: Can't believe I've lived in the hood over 20 years and have never been here.  The service is friendly and attentive and food is perfect in flavors and portion.  Ordered the escargot and calamari appetizers and they had a nice blend of sauces and herbs.  The calamari was not breaded like most places so that was a nice touch.  Entrees were seafood special pasta which we requested spaghetti pasta as substitutes and veal Marsala which were nice and tender.  The lasagna bolognese was the best I've had since there was no ricotta cheese.  If you're looking for a nice Italian meal then visit this place.
author: Shelton F.

description: Amazing food experience here on an impromptu weekday outing! The nightly special seafood curly pasta was rich and delicious! The saltinbocca veal my husband had was the best we have ever tasted. For desert, the whipped egg yolk and tiramisu really finished off a great night! Thank you Gold Mirror!
author: May O.

description:
Old San Francisco.
Old School.
Traditional Italian.

I knew the history here; I have friends that are well over 40, & they used to come here w their parents when they were in grade school.  

On this particular Friday night, the restaurant was full of 
SI & SH alums.  Evidently, that's the case just about every night.

If you're not a native, SI is St. Ignatius, & SH is Sacred Heart.  They're the top 2 private catholic high schools in the city.  They're also notorious rivals.

They basically hate each other.

How can you tell if someone's a real SF native?

By how they answer you when you ask them where they went to school.

If they answer w their high school, then they're SF native.

If they answer w a college, then they're certainly not.

This was a topic at our dinner table w 5 SF natives, & our neighboring table w 3 more.  And, it turned out that they knew each other.

So la famiglia.

Now, the food.  I was struck by all the veal options, & I don't even eat veal.  They're known for their dore, & their cannelloni.  I was told that their cannelloni recipe came straight from a fellow dining companion's mom, who used to own an old Italian restaurant in SF that closed long ago.

Small world, ain't it?
Or, I should say, it's a little city, ain't it?

If you got that reference, then you're a native, or you've been in the city for at least 25 years.  

I didn't expect to run into friends from North Beach, or the club (SFIAC), all the way out here, but that's exactly what happened.  So random.  This is parkside, no where near NB.  It certainly was serendipitous running into friends from the neighborhood & the club, & ultimately dining w them.  But, the piece de resistance was actually my dish.  

I ordered the chicken fettuccine w forest mushrooms.  It's not a dish that they're known for, or even a staple dish for me.  I ordered it just because of the truffle oil element.

It was outstanding.
Maybe the best non-artisan pasta dish I've ever had.

I went home w leftovers, & licked the plate the next day when I polished it off.

Every element here, from the history, to the food, to the staff, made a routine dinner an extraordinary one.

I'm withholding a star for the front windows.  If you're sitting by them, you're right on the muni line, so it's a bit loud.  And it's cold.  

It's not nice dining in the cold.

Not to mention, if you're a real guido, you're way too visible up there.  Stay away from the windows!

Nothing that heavy drapery can't fix, though.

A gem.  4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
The food was poor quality, with many errors in my family's orders. I've never had such a rude waitress. 
Here's a few of her mistakes...
1.) After admitting she brought out the wrong food to me, she stated "I know it's wrong, but the kitchen made it this way so it's not my problem" 
2.) She also stated, "if you don't like it, don't worry I will eat it."
I was shocked and in disbelief when she said this. 
3.) She also brought my elderly grandfather out a plate of RABBIT instead of the CHICKEN he ordered... this is how the next conversation went;
Me-"Excuse me, what is he eating?"
Waitress- "Rabbit"
Me- "he actually ordered the chicken"
Waitress-"I know, but when I gave it to him, he started eating it and I didn't want to take it away."
(He was probably starving after the THREE HOUR (not and exaggeration) wait to get his food.
So the rabbit went back and he got the chicken to go. 
4.)Don't worry. She charged us for BOTH the rabbit he didn't want and was served in error, as well as the chicken. 
5.) I am not sure how someone can miss refilling a water glass 3 times to spill it over my lap on those 3 occasions.

So, after experiencing the crappy food, errors, water spillage, and a rude waitress who was acting completely inebriated, we definitely won't be returning. Do yourselves a favor and don't waste your time or money. At least you won't be accidentally eating Peter Cottontail.
author: L D.

description:
Stopped in for a fine lunch.

Passed by this non descript place many times over the years.

You enter off the street and see a largish room, soft colors, white table cloths, some artistic motifs - upscale looking. Full length sized bar. 

An upscale place, with well heeled clientele. 

I heard the spaghetti and ravioli is good.

And hedged and went for rigatoni and meatball.

They start you out with a basket of  some wonderful crusty bread and quality butter.

Soon, you are brought out your entree. 
The rigatoni had a slightly chewy - in a good way - bite. And, the meat marinara had a fine scent, it was rich and meaty. $17.00 upscale quality.

The cofffee was deep, dark and finished nicely. Kudo's to Gold Mirror Restaurant.

I noted my friends spaghetti and marinara was graced with fresh looking sauteed tomato's.  

Customer service: professional and kind: I felt important. Excellent. Rare.

Parking: seek and find parking!

Decor: old school semi elegant. 

For a few bucks more, enjoy a nice and pleasant place to dine.

Will visit again. And, may move up to 3.5 stars.
author: Bert K.

description:
A hidden gem in the Sunset district. Don't let the exterior fool you. The inside is warm and bustling. I absolutely love the chicken mushroom pasta. If you're into truffley mushroom flavors, this dish is for you.

You can't go wrong with any other dishes. They all use fresh seafood and delicious pasta. Drinks are very affordable here too.
author: Renee L.

description: Love the Gold Mirror!! Old fashioned and delicious Italian food in a warm setting. Visited New Years Eve. It was incredibly busy but service, food, and cocktails were excellent and delivered in a timely manner. Ditto for visit two weeks ago. Getting tired of hipster and millennials versions. Let's go old style.
author: Alston L.

description:
I'm sitting at home at 7:30 on my 50th birthday. Do you know why? Because The Gold Mirror kicked me and my friends OUT of their restaurant after an hour and a half on my birthday. Not because we misbehaved, not because we weren't ordering anything, but because they felt we had spent too much time there, and "other people" were waiting for the table.

I made a reservation and told them we had a person in a wheelchair. The forgot. I told them we had a person coming for dessert. They forgot. Then they kicked us out.

If you enjoy sitting at home rather than with your good friends who you haven't seen in a long time, who have driven a long way to meet you at a restaurant for your birthday---then book at Gold Mirror. Otherwise, go somewhere else. The food and mediocre service certainly doesn't make up for the humiliation of being kicked out.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Wonderful service. The hostess was so nice and Paolo was my amazing server. He made great suggestions and everything tasted delicious.
Some items were a bit expensive for the portions, but the taste readily made up for the small portion.
Beet Salad
Garlic Fried Prawn
Clam Chowder
Chicken and Mushroom Fettuccine (highly recommended)
Swordfish (catch of the day) (highly recommended)
Panettone Bread Pudding (highly recommended)
Italian Cream Cake
author: Lauren R.

description: Food, perfection! Waiters attentive and helpful, but not overbearing. Nice atmosphere, traditional nice restaurant. Worth a trek to the City. We will go back for sure.
author: Cheryl T.

description:
I've always driven by this restaurant for as long as I've lived in SF, and that would be all my life, but never had the opportunity to stop and try the food.

It's New Year's Eve and I wanted to have dinner at a restaurant that I was familiar with and has been known around the neighborhood as a cozy restaurant that you can have a drink or a nice casual meal. 

I loved this place.  It had a Goodfellas feel with the flavor to match.  Good thing that the portions didn't match the girth of some of the guys in that movie.  Nevertheless, is recommend this place.  Parking can be a bear but it shouldn't be too difficult on the street.
author: O ..

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with adult family of four. Bartender was spot on with our drinks. Our cousins who arrived first put us on the list to be seated. There seemed to be a couple of hostesses.  Didn't get their names.  A brunette and a blonde.  The brunette was very nice and gave us updates as to when we would be seated.  Didn't have to wait long...Sweet!

Unfortunately, the overly made up blonde who came to collect us had the demeanor of someone who couldn't care less about you.  She couldn't even be bothered to look you in the eye - would just give you a dismissive sideways look. So sorry to bother you into doing your JOB by escorting us a whole seven feet to our table!

The rest of the evening was a delight. We hadn't been to the Gold Mirror in years but we were all kicking ourselves for staying away for so long.

Our waitress had an adorable personality and made sure we were well taken care of.  It sounded as if she had an Italian accent, which added to the charm.

The calamari appetizer was to die for! It was somewhere between a sauté and a lightly breaded dish. A wonderful, garlicky, buttery, fresh calamari dish.  Two of us had the veal scaloppine. Again, absolutely wonderfully tender and delicious.  I forget what the third one of us had. I had the seafood pasta special. It was fine, with a good amount of fish.  (Not bad, just got a little jealous that the other two dishes were so great.)

The wine by the bottle selection was very nice at decent prices.

This is a classic San Franciscan experience (except for the blonde ).  We will definitely return sooner rather than later! Calamari...mmm!
author: Larry And Cathy G.

description: This was worth revisiting San Francisco and the outer avenues. The menu , the place reminded me of old Temescal of my youth here in Oakland. The service was good in a full room. As an appetizer we had wonderful calamari , sautéed in a wonderful light garlic infused sauce, not at all like the over fried tough stuff that makes you not want to order this, we had two salads , an average Cesar that could've had a bit more oomph . The second was a divine burrata on delicious tomatoes , with prosciutto . My wife's entree was the Canneloni very cheesy and mine was a rich veal parmigiana . Very rich and good. Got desert we had a wonderful tiramisu . I have been so disappointed in this dish that I stopped ordering it as it always looked and tasted like something from Costco , quick and cheap. This was wonderful and restored my love for this dish. All in all very much worth the trip to Frisco from the good side of the Bay
author: Earl P.

description:
I hadn't been to this place in over 10 years, and boy oh boy, am I glad I returned. This place is as good as I remember it. 

This place is perfect for ALL occasions: business dinner, catching up with friends, romantic date, family gathering, you name it. But the best action happens at the bar: you can meet new people, and overhear conversations from long-time regulars and SF natives! The bartender Christian takes good care of you, and he's also an SF native. I recommend sitting at the bar, loading up on the cheese & crackers, then ordering a drink and a small appetizer. You can easily get a meal for less than $20 here. 

If you like that old-school Italian restaurant swag and don't want to go to Joe's of Westlake or North Beach, this is where you must go!
author: Maurice R.

description:
Cute decor indoors and great service but the food wasn't memorable. The salmon was good and I chose to upgrade to housemate fettuccine alfredo pasta for a $7 up charge instead of the rice which I enjoyed. The rice pilaf that typically accompanies the meals is literally Rice-a-Roni- pay the up charge to switch it to something else! Also pretty small portions for the price point. 

It was a good experience and a great meal but nothing innovative or exciting. Pretty straightforward menu with lots of warm bread to begin. 

Would recommend the *housemade pasta (they have other pastas at a cheaper price point) but save your money on the calamari - beyond drenched in oil and not worth it! Loved my waiter also!
author: Samyutha R.

description:
Since coming to San Francisco more than a decade ago I have been enamored of the "modern" Italian restaurants within the city.  You know, places like Delfina, Cotogna, Flour and Water, and Perbacco.  Gold Mirror is considered old style Italian, and while some things recommend it, I now know why new Italian has gained favor.  

On entering I found the hostess talking on her cell phone.  Soon it became apparent that she was helping an older patron get just the right reservation.  Good for the hostess.  And she seated me at the best table available.  Good for the hostess. 

My server approached abruptly and asked what I wanted.  As it turned out I did: Pasta and then fish.  He suggested a half order of pasta and then the fish.  Good for the server.  He may have been a bit abrupt but he was helpful.

Another thing that the Gold Mirror has to recommend itself is pricing: Gold Mirror is easy on the wallet. 

My half order of  fettucini with grilled chicken, wild mushrooms and truffle oil arrived and my server was right, a half order was plenty.  The mushrooms were there and nice, likewise the chicken, but while the pasta was al dente it was bland.  And in my humble opinion, truffle oil should be discarded.  It has an overwhelming scent and it masks the taste of everything else on the plate. Many people would think this was a good plate of pasta but I longed for the deep, rich flavors of sugo of the sort that covers pasta at Perbacco.

Filet of sole meuniere was not to my taste.  The large portion of fish was bland, under seasoned, and mushy as though it had seen the inside of a freezer.  The green beans that accompanied the fish were a bit overcooked and had lost any hint of snap.  The rice that came with the fish was OK. 

It's not that Gold Mirror isn't a good place, it's just that I've become an Italian food snob and expect a bit more from the food.
author: David D.

description:
This is a fun place for both dinner for two or a bigger group, like 6.

Have eaten here at least 4 times in last few years, originally ate here in 1982 as a SFSU sophomore. 

Nice cocktail selection. ALWAYS HAPPY TO SEE VEAL ON A MENU!!! pasta is all good as well.
author: Nat D.

description: The Gold Mirror could be a very good restaurant, but the service is among the worst. We grew up in this Taraval St. neighborhood and have been dining at the Gold Mirror on and off since the 1980's. We have many fond memories of countless wonderful meals at the Gold Mirror with its warm, friendly, and always professional staff. But such a staff seems not to exist anymore. Today's dining experience was ruined by our waiter's indifference and the awful service. We had lunch, and the restaurant was hardly crowded. After being ignored for more than 10 minutes, we flagged down the waiter. He could care less whether or not we ordered. He was rude, almost annoyed and said something like "Did you want a drink?" We ordered wine, soups and entrees. The soups appeared immediately, the drinks came later...no time to enjoy the drinks first. After the entrees were served, there was no more waiter. Trying to get a second glass of wine took two requests, a reminder and another long delay. Too bad that a lack of service affects a restaurant we had greatly enjoyed and have a long history with. The food is still good, but we won't go back. Service counts. The manner is which guests are treated is unacceptable. Why would the Gold Mirror keep a waiter who has a 100% negative effect and who clearly disdains the job that he is supposed to be doing?
author: Mary R.

description: HAVE TO GIVE ONE STAR, UNFORTUNATELY.   We went here with a party of ten and we had a reservation.    When we got there, the place was fairly empty.   I don't know if we had a waiter in training but the tables that filled around us got their food well after our orders had been in.   In fact, the waiter couldn't be bothered with drinks, which were wrong or forgotten,  before he was rushing us to order.   Food was disappointing when it finally did get to the table.   Steaks over cooked and sent back , prime rib too salty - as if it had been double salted and dry potatoes.   Don't expect any butter or sour cream for the cold potatoes because several people asked the waiter several times to no avail.   For the cost of the meal,  portion size, taste and service....stay home and microwave something!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Gold mirror, what a named place.  You find street parking, then come into the restaurant threw heavy velvet curtains to the bar area. 
You see the hostess at the end of the bar , ask for a table. Get seated in a super tight table . Within arms reach of the next table. There wasn't even enough room to walk in between so I had to navigate around several tables to sit across of my wife. 
Service was kinda a miss but I am not a big deal if the food is on point. Get the standard fair in any New Italian restaurant we try. Spaghetti Bolognese, and clams pasta. Both are on point and very rich and tasty cell service, wasn't the main point. Price is below average $17 for pasta plate up to $30 for steak. Noise level at this restaurant is very high. Oh a party came in and it smelled like college all over again. I guess it was for the glaucoma. That party was seated in the upstairs banquet area.
author: Jesse S.

description: I was really looking forward to eating here because of the reviews. I got veal cannelloni, which was good but not great. Service was good but a little understaffed, I came in late and there was a little mini rush I don't think they were ready for, so getting refills on water and bread took a while and they seemed a bit preoccupied when they were taking my order, but they were very friendly. I like the ambiance, and would come again to give them another shot even though I felt it was a bit overpriced, $25 cup soup, and cannelloni that were just ok.
author: James M.

description:
Hubby wanted to dine here again as it has been a few years. You can tell a lot of regulars in the neighborhood come here. He thought his minestrone soup was OK. I really liked my Caesar salad , $8, with a sliver of anchovy and you could taste it in the dressing. Next time, I am just going to get a big salad. 

Jr Yelpers liked their tortellini and veal Parmesan. Hubby liked his entree as well. I didn't so much like my calamari steak which was coated in flour and pan fried.  I would have liked it coated in bread crumbs. I gave the Jr Yelpers each a bite and neither liked it. Came with veggies and rice. The calamari was bland but I was glad they didn't over salt the food. Not so good for those seniors who are regulars there. More than enough food as portions were big. Service was OK.
author: Ry T.

description:
Perhaps the worst restaurant experience we've had in the past thirty plus years.  Though we had a reservation for dinner on Thursday evening (2/22/2018) the Gold Mirror sat four of us at a table in the midst of eight other tables which were occupied by a team of 12 persons conducting business with other persons who were not patrons of the restaurant, and did not order food (but were occasionally treated by those working to tea or a tidbit). These 12 walked between tables, back and forth constantly (I should mention the tables are tightly spaced with barely room for service people to squeeze by) and eventually, not happy with the never ending disruption, I asked one of them exactly what they were doing.  As it turns out they use the restaurant instead of an office to work with persons who wish to divest themselves of "time share" investments they no longer want or need.
That the restaurant (a very small one) would use its space at dinner time on a crowded Thursday night in this manner is questionable at best  -   but that we would be seated in the midst of those tables is unforgivable and demonstrates total lack of one of the fundamental tenants of restaurant management - customer service.
The restaurant's white table cloths and decor belie what is a crowded, noisy, lazy space.  The servers were lax, perhaps overworked (there were obviously not enough of them), one member of our party received his entree at least five minutes after everyone else.  The bill arrived prior to our being asked about dessert  -   and was incorrect (a total of $36 for dinner for four), and we eventually received a corrected one - but now we see that we have been charged for both.
The food was ok if unremarkable -  historically San Francisco is home to many, many  fine and ordinary Italian restaurants which deliver both family and haute cuisine  -  and Gold Mirror should not be listed among them.
author: Nancy P.

description:
This restaurant represents that real old school old bay love. And I don't mean old bay seasoning. I mean old San Franciscan class, elegance, ambience, sophistication and cuisine. 

Been coming here since I was a kid. I remember the old days when they had the huge "dinners". If you're old school you know what I'm talking about. 

Came back here tonight and had the most satisfying experience. 

Service was excellent. Food was on point. Wasn't rushed and treated like royalty. 

Started with the hearts of Palm salad. Could have eaten three of those and called it a night. Fiancé ordered the broiled petrale sole. It was seasoned and cooked to perfection. I ordered the tortellini. It was delicate and fresh. Desserts are authentic and house made. Sooo decadent. Though we didn't order the fried calamari, every table in the joint was eating it. It looked and smelled delish. 

Also, it should be noted that there was a hot bartender and a smoking hot waiter working tonight. All the waiters are dressed in tuxedos which can't hurt. Got nothing but love for The Gold Mirror. Xoxo.
author: Rosalyn W.

description: They've improved the service tremendously since my last review and are very attentive to diners. The lasagna is the best I've ever had - homemade pasta, meaty sauce, fresh mozzarella, slightly crispy from the broiler - delicious!  People of all ages are welcome and it's getting a younger vibe, even though still old school Italian. Parking can be tough but atmosphere is nice once you're inside.
author: Michelle O.

description: After eating at neighborhood Italian places in Noe Valley and West Portal I have to say that GM is by far the best and the best deal. Prawns Dore was outstanding.
author: Jon R.

description:
Great neighborhood spot in the Outer Sunset for lunch or dinner. I love this place for authentic Italian food in SF (outside of North Beach).  The pasta is made fresh, which makes their lasagna absolutely heaven.  The calamari appetizer is great - it is sautéed in olive oil & garlic rather than the awful way other restaurants make it by deep-frying it in a thick batter.  The garlic bread is toasted/broiled and has chunks of garlic in its butter topping.  

Save room for dessert!  They make their tiramisu exactly the way it is supposed to be made - with rum-soaked lady fingers.  Delicious!

Great for family gatherings!
author: Chilly W.

description:
Classic old school charm 4 stars

food 5 stars

Service 3 Star

Ya should go here not in a hurry and you will leave with a smile.
author: Jeff G.

description: Saw a review for Gold Mirror on Check Please and it looked so good we had to go and check it out for ourselves. Went on a week night and it did not disappoint!! Started with the obscenely good calamari that was absolutely fantastic!! Then had the lasagna which was some of the best I've had at any Italian restaurant! Would absolutely go back and feel that the service and the food was well worth the price that was paid. Really nice home-style environment and excellent quality without breaking the bank. Saw many different things that I would like to go back and try and would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a good Italian meal at a very reasonable price!
author: Nick J.

description: Good food, great service, a/c place. for the price you get a lot !!! will go there again when in SF.
author: LUDMILA G.

description: We went to this restaurant on Thursday night and there were 5 of us for dinner! My parents have enjoyed this place for over 20 years and I must say the service was awful! They were short staffed and had 1 busboy for the entire place! I think there may have been 2 waiters on duty for the entire place which was somewhat full at 6 pm! Several tables seemed dissatisfied and were glancing around for more wine, drinks, and the like! Some folks even got out of their chairs and went and got what they needed! We were happy to get our meal 40 minutes later and our appetizer of garlic bread arrived 5 min before the main course! So, as you can see service was poor and our dinner would have been good but was disappointing! Not sure I would recommend or go here again when suggested as a place to go!
author: Sheila O.

description: Love that this place has a great old school bar with bartenders that make excellent drinks quickly. The food on the other hand was a bit hit and miss. We ordered the lasagna which was awesome, but I would skip the tortellini. Unfortunately, the wine is overpriced which gave us heartache that the final bill turned out to be $120 per person. That is too much for a nice (but not Michelin starred) neighborhood Italian place. I would also suggest not sitting upstairs as the service sometimes forgot about us. Bottom line, good food, but overpriced.
author: Jason P.

description: We noticed the restaurant from SF muni and decided to give it a try after reading some reviews. We were pleasantly surprised! Started off with a cocktail at the BAR which had a complementary cheese/cracker tray on the bar. Haven't seen one of those in a LONG time. We were seated for dinner quickly and ordered an appetizer of escargot (excellent and meaty) and my wife had the calamari dore and I had the lasagna (very rich). Service was excellent but a little quick as it almost appeared they wanted to turn the table for the next guests. We split the chocolate sundae which was also very good. Overall a good meal, good value, neighbor gem, great for groups, but not quite a five star experience nor the price.
author: Jim C.

description: Great place! Although the quantity is less, the quality is decent and the food is tasty. I would say its a $$$ restaurant.
author: Kailash M.

description: I'd absolute go back.  What I had was great but we only had appetizers.  Got to go back hungry and I'll edit this review.
author: Andy T.

description:
Saw Gold Mirror featured on Check Please, Bay Area and decided to try it when kids were out of the house for the evening.  It's not a terrible drive from Palo Alto, and gave us a chance to bop around SF after dinner.

We ordered some things featured on the show and tried a few others.  Wife had eggplant, I ordered lasagna, a friend got veal and another friend got some other pasta dish.  The eggplant was forgettable, lasagna was good, "other" pasta dish was good and the veal was very good.  We also ordered calamari and oysters as appetizers.  Oysters were ok; calamari was the best portion of the meal.

Solid enough food, but not the 'wow' I expected.  $50 per person with dessert; we brought our own wine.  I expect more than 'solid' at that price.
author: Andy B.

description:
When you first walk into Gold Mirror, you see the fake door painted on one side, a small, sequestered bar area on the other, and a small dining room in between. I hope you remember the old adage of not judging a book by its cover at that point, because looks are very deceiving in this case. Drinks at the bar are made promptly and courteously by a very sociable bartender, and the food is fantastic. Trust the reviews, start with the calamari, and you're golden from that point forward. Breaded, but not fried, you get both the calamari steak portion and the legs, and they're both seasoned perfectly and very tender.

If you're not feeling the drive all the way out to North Beach, I'd say Gold Mirror would be the place to go. It's a little on the pricey side, but you're good solid quality food and great service.
author: Danny C.

description:
I never wanted to go to a restaurant so much in my life since seeing this one mentioned on "Check, Please" TV program. What a disappointment!  And we headed up from the Morgan Hill/San Jose area just for this eatery that proved a less than memorable trek.  

The fried calamari everyone raved about was greasy. And it was old grease. Not light and one you could hardly taste. Needed sauces served with it, more lemon. I have had way better at lesser a place. We so wish that the bread would have been brought warm and the butter soft.  Had a glass of house white wine - so so.

My dining companion was polite and did not finish her lunch. It was fish, not seasoned well and served with dull vegetables.  I had the canelloni - which again was rated as fabulous.  It was all right, but I've had finer in my time...And it repeated on me 2 hours later. The pasta did not taste better the second time around.  Sorry.  And I failed to bring antacids with me. 

Dessert was cannoli - it was good, but I don't prefer chocolate on mine. I grew up in the North End of Boston where we never had chocolate. House coffee was described as weak by our server, so my companion passed.   

Service was scant. Our water glasses got down. It was not crowded.  I must say that the prices are reasonable - especially for SF.  Atmosphere fun. But, this was NOT the dining experience I expected...Expected to wowed... I am no longer going to watch "Check, Please."  I finally got to a place claimed A++, but it rated a D+.  Argh!

Glass Mirror, in essence, is not cracked up to what is purported to be. :(
author: Why Y.

description:
Now that was a dose of theater I didn't sign up for!

Used to frequent the GM every Friday for years with a dear friend, so when we heard the owners son had taken over and renewed the menu (and with good referrals) we went for a birthday night.

Bottom line is our waiter was rude, offensive and insulting. This guy became hostile when asked some very basic questions about the wine menu. And, I mean basic. When asked for a recommendation on "earthy wines" he just snapped, threw a bottle on the table and stated "this is the wine". No suggestions, other info or alternatives offered up. Ok, let's try and ask someone else? Nope, he insisted with a stern declaration "I am the wine expert here". I kid you not.

That was about as helpful as this guy was gonna get, and from that point things plummeted further.

We were ready to walk out. How can anyone enjoy dinner with an opening volley of insults du jour from the waiter with 'tude?

Before our entrées arrived a lady sat next to us with heavy perfume, so we discreetly asked to be moved to one of the many empty tables. Now that just sent him into an incoherent rant. Banged plates and napkins muttering away while moving us  Ok, is it theater night here or what?

Only reason we get 2 stars is the Front of House Manager Jackie. She was gracious and courteous. She came by and was very understanding and informative about a select few wines. They are lucky to have her. 

I'd venture back sometime if some changes are made, as the food was quite delicious. But sorry, not gonna fork over $$ for a side of unnecessary snarkyness. Hope things improve.
author: Kenneth S. L.

description:
The Gold Mirror is wonderful and I highly recommend it! We have been going for last 10 years and it stays consistantly great. Some of my favorites are:
Artichoke appetizer with olives (seasonal) - devine
I luv the caesar salad and my husband enjoys the avocado suffed with fresh crab.
All the pastas are excellent, Gold Mirror's balance of within their sauces, is spot on!
A must are the jumbo prawns dore and the veal milanese.
The wine list is not large but the selection is outstanding.
author: Teresa L.

description: Like others, I've driven or walked by this place for the 11 years I've lived in San Francisco. And I've always lived in the neighborhood. I have a friend who great up in The City and said he went here with his family for special occasions in the 70s. So we decided to try it on the spur of the moment. I had hoped for something more old school and less Brooklyn Renaissance. I think someone decided to "remodel" in the 90s and probably ruined the old fashioned decor ... Replacing it with more of a tacky decor than anything else. Although I do love the chandeliers and the "gold mirror" on the wall. That said, I didn't hate the decor. It was fun and kitschy. But I just wished for something more original to when the restaurant opened. The food was quite delicious. Although I would've liked my marinara sauce to be thicker and less watery. I have a feeling they don't serve much marinara sauce. It certainly wasn't anything memorable. Everything on the menu seemed to be strongly meat oriented. Marinara sauce wasn't even on the menu as a choice with pasta. My co-diners had lasagna and enjoyed it. The bread was superb. Crispy on the outside and soft and warm inside. One place where this restaurant lost lots of points was their charging for soda refills. Come on guys, this isn't the 1970s. Businesses have been giving free refills on sodas for nearly 30 years. And to make matters worse. To not even tell the customer that you're charging them for another soda when they ask for a refill. This seems to me as a very low brow way of taking advantage of your customers. Especially for a place that seems high brow.  Charging for soda refills, that cost you literally 5 or 10 cents is just plain tacky. Other than that, the service was very good, if not just a tad snooty. Maybe our waiter didn't expect much from us. We left him a $30 tip. So we might've changed his opinion of us in the end.
author: Daniel S.

description: I must say I was very impressed.  It is "old school".  White table clothes and cloth napkins.  A little laid back.  We arrived with a reservation, but the hostess was seating a "party" in the upstairs.  There were plenty of tables.  So we sat at the bar and ordered drinks while we waited for the rest of our party.  Bar tender was top notch and made a wonderful drinks and chatted us up.  Once our whole party arrived, we were seated right away and we got our menus.  Specials were explained and we made our choices .  Prosciutto Tortellini, Short Rib Ravioli, Veal Parmigiana, Cannelloni, and one special. The food came out in a nice flow.  We all tasted each others food.  The pasta was so fresh and good.  It was all good.  They kept the drinks and water coming.  I had the cannoli ... yummy.    I wanted to take part of my main dish, I didn't even have to ask for a "to go box"... our waiter noticed and brought me the box.  Then we went for a dessert tour. We ordered 5 different things and shared.  For me the Italian Cream Cake was over the top.    Our waiter had been working there for over 25 yr.  He was top notch.  That is a rarity these days.  I look forward to going back soon the try other items.
author: India G.

description:
For the price, this is one of the best places in SF, especially in Sunset.

Group of 4 came at 7:45pm Sunday night, seated within 5 minutes. Cute little Italian restaurant with old world charm and dim moodlighting, not a bad choice for a 2nd or 3rd date. Or whatever date you want, I'm a reviewer not a cop.

2 orders of Bolognese Lasagne, noodles and sauce were prepared wonderfully.
1 order Eggplant Parmigian for the vegetarian in our group, crispy and well-balanced, not too thick a slice of Eggplant.
1 order of veal Cannelloni, although the cheese was more the star of the dish than the meat itself.

Overall, the food was definitely outstanding.

-1 star because the other patrons were annoying. They seemed to be regulars, treating the establishment like a common bar and raising the ambient volume to irksome levels. 

Our poor server was getting yelled at by another table as they loudly butchered the Italian language with constant calls of "Excuse-ay. Sir! Can I get another glass of the Pinot No-Ire. Graci...umm, graciamente"

Eventually he started avoiding their table because they were loud and terrible, but that meant we didn't get served very quickly either. 

But I don't blame him, I blame the frat guys who didn't realize they were 45 years old and their harpy female companions. I thought on a Sunday I could avoid hearing "BRUH! DID YOU GET YOUR DICK WET?! BRUH, I F***ED HER GOOD" unnecessarily shouted by the table next to me, but for some people the best things in life are their high school sports activities from 30 years prior and shouting them loudly at the only other people on earth who would possibly care
author: Jack S.

description:
This trip to Gold Mirror was not as good as the first time...

The restaurant was almost painfully dark - it was difficult to read the menu...we had to utilize the tiny candle fixture at the table/cell phones. It might have seemed darker because we were sat in the corner this time as opposed to closer to the door/windows last time.

My family ordered a variety of appetizers to start our meal. The calamari was very good...I liked that it wasn't overly breaded and fried like most. It was also generously tossed in olive oil and garlic, a welcomed spread to the toasted bread. The roasted artichokes were also excellent. The hearts were tender and there were definitely enough pieces such that everyone got to try some. Likewise, we also utilized the tapenade that came with the roasted artichokes as a spread. The most disappointing appetizer was the crab salad...while the pieces of fresh crab were very large (most likely the claws)...the "salad" was more coleslaw like and tossed in this very heavy dressing. You couldn't even taste the crab because the dressing was so heavy!

For my main, I ordered the lamb loin stuffed with mushrooms and spinach with a side of polenta. The lamb was amazingly tender, cooked perfectly! A nice seared edge with a juicy interior. The polenta though, was not as creamy and smooth as I would have liked, instead it was allowed to firm (to serve as a "stage" for the lamb). Meh. For the most part, my family thoroughly enjoyed their meals though...with a couple exceptions. My grandmother also had to trade dishes with my dad, her veal was just way too salty. My dad initially felt like his salmon was also overcooked.  

For dessert, I wanted to try the italian sponge cake - but they were out. Doesn't matter how early you are here - something always runs out...they need to assess their inventory better.

Instead, we had the chilled zabaglione and the tiramisu. The tiramisu was presented differently than most. Instead of as a dusted cake, it had the cream in the center with the lady fingers as a fortress. It wasn't heavy on the alcohol either - which was nice for a dessert. The chilled zabaglione was pretty good too. The custard was nice and there wasn't a lot of wine flavor either - just enough to hit the spot.

Our waiter Paulo (or Paolo?) was great though. His service was on point and he was funny. He comped the tiramisu for my birthday too!
author: Elaine Y.

description: The decor it's amazing. No wonder why this restaurant has been here for the last 40 something years. The food was very good, Caesar salad, minestrone soup and the spaghetti and clams. Great flavors all over. The service was very good and attentive. Hostess, server and bussers work very well as a team to make everybody feel good. Very nice experience. We'll be back.
author: Harold F.

description: Old school Italian with some wonderful food. We had the kurobuta pork chop which was juicy and well complemented by the fruit enhanced sauce. The lasagna is simply ethereal with melt in your mouth housemade noodles and a creamy, rich and delicious sauce and cheese. This is nothing like those stiff, dry multilayer lasagnas with rubbery cheese. The butter lettuce and pear salad and the Caesar are also worthy of mention.
author: Gail N.

description: Great food, great service and great atmosphere.  Parking may be challenging at certain times but it's worth it!   Love the salmon dishes...yum!
author: Woodstock B.

description: My go-to place for Italian food on the west side of SF. I've never been disappointed with my meal - always delicious!
author: Matt Y.

description: I love this place. Excellent service and the food is always good. Calamari is best I have ever had. Great bar and wine selection. Very old school and classy. LOVE.
author: Katrena M.

description:
This place is great if you are craving an old school american italian food.

A group of 4 of us walked in without reservations - we started off at the bar.  I ordered a manhattan that was delicious so I had two!

The food was also very good.  We ordered calamari for the table.  It was very lightly battered and everyone loved it!

The main course menu itself was fancier than I was expecting, but unfortunately also more expensive than I was expecting.  I had the veal sweetbreads, which was delicious.  My fellow diners dishes, the spaghetti and clams bordelaise, veal milanese, etc looked equally appetizing.

However, when it came to desserts, we were all underwhelmed.  So I would recommend skipping desserts and just ordering more drinks from the bar :)
author: Angelito R.

description:
As my first review got filtered out a long time ago, let me just say in the immortal words of Charles Barkley: "Terrible"

Just. Terrible. 

Food was OK, but in terrible, small portions. Service was terrible.  On Terrival street.  Even if you're just hungry for Italian, just... Don't.
author: Darren W.

description: Really delicious truffle fettuccini. It was salty and creamy - which I like. And the noodles were fresh! Bf got lasagna and it was interesting - flatter and noodley.
author: Steph N.

description:
After a long Sunday playing tourist in San Francisco with a native San Franciscan, we were looking forward to a nice meal, and the Gold Mirror certainly delivered. 

We came to dine here for my mother's birthday, and it was a marvelous experience! We were greeted by a friendly host, and our service throughout was very good. The food was excellent, and the warm bread and cool butter was very much needed prior to our meal being served (I was starting to get HANGRY!). 

I started with the minestrone soup; which was probably one of the best that I have had anywhere! My entree was a fettuccine pasta with cream sauce, and I added prawns to the dish. This was also quite excellent - freshly made in-house pasta blanketed with a thin layer of the perfect combination of butter/garlic/cream sauce, and the prawns were perfectly seasoned with garlic. My parents also equally enjoyed both of their dishes. The presentation of the meals was also quite lovely. 

This is a delightful Italian restaurant. If you want quintessential San Francisco Italian dining at its best, there is no need to venture off (fight traffic and parking) to North Beach. You should instead visit the Gold Mirror. I know I will definitely be back to this restaurant, and I will certainly recommended this establishment to others.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
Timeless, old-school charm.

Entering Gold Mirror is like stepping back in time a little.  You settle in for dinner service, and suddenly you honestly don't care about the hustle of the daytime world. 

Warm bread and wine (or water, if you don't partake) keep you and company nibbling while pondering the menu.  Refreshingly, this is an Italian place that doesn't bombard the menu with twelve pages of "customize-a-pasta" offerings.  Sure, there are great pasta dishes, really delectable ones- I've pretty much ordered them all.  But also steaks, fish, chicken dishes that are undeniably Italian, without being a "step-up-from-Olive-Garden".  

Staff are friendly, attentive, and will take time to talk about their personal favorites, or chat a little with you and your guests.  You don't feel "above" them, you feel welcomed in by them, guided, and at ease.  Guests are invited to take their time- and since I often have trouble deciding on my entree and wine pairing, I honestly do appreciate the staff chatting with me about what they like and recommend, in a completely amiable way.

Every meal spent at Gold Mirror has been just a lovely, low-key experience.  Dinner is great and balanced and filling, and the desserts are excellent, on the few occasions I have had tummyspace to tuck into one.

A date night go-to for my sweetheart and I, we've never been anything but absolutely  delighted to enjoy a dinner at Gold Mirror.
author: Marisa D.

description:
I read a previous Yelp review and decided to try the calamari and was very pleased with the just right amount of garlic used to flavor it. 
They have four different varieties of Mary's Ranch chicken which I am pretty sure is all organic and free range raised which matters to me. 
I opted for the saute sec chicken which had an excellent flavorful sauce and a side of steamed carrots, vegetables and rice.
Overall I am very pleased with the Gold Mirror and will likely return soon.
author: Jayeson V.

description:
First impressions are huge for any business- unfortunately being a neighbor to Gold Mirror, I've seen that for almost a year, their exterior fluorescent sign has been missing multiple letters and their sneeze guard has graffiti etchings which doesn't exactly lure you in.

But like I said, as a neighbor, this is a place I have always wanted to try-

Service was good.

Food was good too- I had the eggplant Parmesan and cup of mushroom soup (both vegetarian) and my boyfriend had the lasagna and minestrone. 

Overall: ambiance + taste + service + price = B-
author: Danielle L.

description:
Gold Mirror is an old school Italian restaurant with an updated menu.  I grew up near this restaurant but only recently paid my first visit.  I've been here a few times with my family and it the perfect place for those both young and old and is most definitely a neighborhood spot.

When you first enter the restaurant be prepared to take some time for your eyes to adjust to the darkness.  When they are adjusted, look around at the decor and be prepared to step back in time.  The tables are situated fairly close to one another and the noise level is high.  The conversation is lively, the martinis are flowing and 
everyone seems to be having a good time.  The waitstaff is dressed in tuxedos, which is a nice touch.

Although the decor is of the past, the menu is not.  Some dishes have been updated with a modern twist and all dishes I've tried here have been quite good.   The pasta dishes are not heavy and overly cheesed (is that a word?).  One dish that stands out is the lasagna, which consists of thin sheets of handmade pasta with ricotta and sauce.  It's not the brick that is served at many Italian restaurants.  The chicken and veal dishes are also quite good.  The pasta dishes I've tried have all been cooked well and are well seasoned.

While the service has been spotty at times, perhaps because the restaurant has always been full on my visit, I've never experienced anything that would prevent me from returning.  On my visits we have had at least five people people in the party and we have always left satisfied.  We have never had to wait to be seated upon arrival.  Reservations are a must.  

Parking is generally available nearby.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Over 4 years since my last meal here.... and I'm ok with that.

I was part of a group of 50 or so and we had the upstairs "loft" room.   It was a birthday for a family member.   

On my way in, I run into an old friend who is leaving.   We say hi and goes out of the way to tell me, "Don't get the calamari, it was horrible".    Advice appreciated, I avoided the calamari.  

We got there at 6PM and we had an hour or so of socializing.   I thought it was a nice touch to have a big rat trap in the rafters directly above the dinner tables.   Kind of gross....We sat down and at 7, they took our order.

A salad shows up 45 minutes later and a pasta dish a bit after that....

Then we wait... and wait.. and wait.... for the main course.  The main course made it to the table, one by one over a 40 minute period.   I was one of the last to get mine exactly 2 hours and 13 minutes after ordering and most people were done eating by the time I got mine.   It was so bad, one couple had to leave(child care issues)  before the food came because they didn't think it would take over 3 hours to get your food for an event that started at 6PM.  

The food itself was average at best... Nothing I would go out of my way for.   The service was friendly but sooooo slow.

I would avoid this place and definitely not throw a big party here... They can't get the food out quick enough.

I won't be going back unless dragged here for another family event.
author: David W.

description:
Very old school - you won't find a lot of greens here. But the meat quality is fantastic. The pasta is homemade and delicious. And what few know is that they have gorgeous aged steaks, best I've had in this city and reminds me of steaks i'd buy at Citronella in NYC. 

The only downside are their wines, but its the kind of place a martini or a scotch on the rocks makes more sense anyway.
author: KE M.

description:
I would come back again and again and again- for their Calamari. It has completely raised the bar for all  Calamari out there now. (It was the only thing my husband and I craved while we were away on a trip.) Our table of 4 also shared the Dungeness crab salad and the fresh Burrata. No complaints.

I also had the Chicken Cacciatore. It was so full of flavor and cooked perfectly, it's hard to fault! The portion is slightly too big for me, so I ditched the veg to finish the chicken. My husband's lamb loin was seasoned and cooked perfectly, he didn't stop until the plate was clean.

The service is ok, sometimes the staff may seem a little stretched. But they get points for trying at least. We were there on a Fri night in Dec, so they were really busy- but trust me, the food is worth the wait!
author: Farah A.

description: Pretty disappointed with this place. Last week I called in and got a reservation for 2 at 8. I show up with my wife about 5 minutes early. Tell the lady there that we have a reservation. She tells us that they are a little backed up and it will be a few minutes. As me and my wife are waiting. A party of 2 walks in with no reservation and gets seated almost immediately. And they get a balcony table. Then another party of 3 walks up from the bar and they get seated. I asked the lady in the party if they had a reservation. The lady told me no they didn't have one. Then a party of 6 walks in. They did have a reservation and got seated within 5 minutes. Well it took them till 8:27 to seat my wife and me. And the real bs to all of this is they give us the table closest to the door in this little corner. This table had been empty of customers sense 8:05. It took them 22 minutes to clear off a table for a couple with a reservation. A table that's 3 foot by 3 foot! And gave to balcony  table to a couple without a reservation. Service was okay. Nothing special. They did bring bread and water frequently. But they should put ice in the water. Water is better cold. The meal was good, but basic. Nothing special. In total it took them 2 hours and 15 minutes to get us out the door. When I go out I expect to be out the door in an hour and a half. If you go here, you're taking a chance.
author: Dan T.

description: So I decided to try a local place for some authentic Italian cuisine, and found this place. The service was A1, super polite, and attentive. The ambiance was excellent as well. I enjoyed the environment, and the layout. The food was good, not great, but not bad at all. It definitely a placed I'd go back.
author: Frisco K.

description: Very expensive for what you get.  The food at the restaurant is decent. It is tasty. However, it's very expensive, and the portion sizes are small.  When you look at the ambiance and the location, you think you will get a pretty good deal on Italian food. However, it's just as expensive as some of the top restaurants in SF, which have much more creativity, better ambiance, and avant-garde cuisine.  The wait staff can be somewhat haughty and condescending, FYI. They have probably been working there for 20 years with local customers, and they really couldn't care less about pleasing any new guests.  They aren't rude, but you can tell that if you said anything wrong or wanted anything out of the ordinary, they would be upset.  They are curt and not very gracious or welcoming, however.  The food, however, is quite tasty.  There is no question that if you want good Italian food, this place is pretty good.  However, just be warned that the wait staff are not super nice, the portion sizes aren't huge, and the prices are high.
author: Gunnar F.

description: I don't care what anyone has written before about Gold Mirror because I love this place. I am a native San Franciscan of Italian descent. I love the food; it's Italian, not some fusion Italian but the real deal. Fusilli a la Norma is perhaps the best pasta dish I had in a long time. It's fusilli pasta with eggplant tomatoes. OMG, it is awesome. Trust me.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Went on New Years Eve & they had a set menu! The food was ok 
Was disappointed the calamari wasn't an appetizer on the menu!
The service  was HORRIBLE!!!  Our waiter didn't even ask us if we wanted coffee  with our dessert!
He put  the dessert on our table & scurried off before we could even ask!
At All the other tables, the server checked to see if there was anything else needed !
Our waiter never did!
I could see if it was busy but there were at least 6  or 7 empty tables 
I won't be going back anytime soon!!!!!
author: Arleen E.

description: The food is delicious, and the menu is great. I usually order calamari, and one of the veal options. The crab stuffed avocado is excellent, so is the homemade lasagna. I was surprised to see this place on Check Please and after watching the show I can't wait to try the calamari steak. Also it is very enjoyable to hang out at the bar. Every time I'm there I have either ran into an old friend from grammar school or high school or met another native San Franciscan who knows someone in my family. Also the entire staff is excellent, friendly, and welcoming.
author: John H.

description: We decided to hold our reunion last minute at Gold Mirror. Jacque was able to accommodate our group of 15. When we got there every thing was set up and ready to go for us. There were additional people that came, they were able to make room for the additional 4 people who arrived. The food was yummy. The service was on point. They were very patient with our group because we kept being in the way by the kitchen. The drinks were great, I had a Dirty Martini.I loved how they made my drink that I had 3 Dirty Martini's! I would definitely recommend the Gold Mirror to dine at!
author: Christine E.

description: We decided to try Gold Mirror after seeing it on Check Please Bay Area. It is clearly a neighborhood favorite judging by the crowd and deafening noise level. The food is Italian American and mediocre. The service is rushed and indifferent at best, borderline rude. The tables are so tightly crammed in, every time somebody had to pass by, they bumped my chair. There's no reason to go back.
author: smrt O.

description: We went in a big group.  Oddly we all ordered either broiled or poached salmon.  No it wasn't Friday...  Cooked both ways the salmon was delicious and fresh.  Many of us also had the avocado salad with shrimp to start.  The fish was very fresh and every thing was delicious.  The menu is very reasonably priced.  Our server was a lovely Italian girl.  I would definitely like to come back and try more items on the menu!
author: Keeping It Real K.

description: Perhaps my favorite restaurant in the city.  An old standby for many a gem for the new.  Great food and staff.  I just love it.  My gf who is 100% Italian loves the food.  Great wine list to boot.  The atmosphere is old school but inviting.  Most of the regulars start at the bar then have dinner.  The seats along the back wall are great the way the are arranged.  Perfect for a date night.  I cant wait to go again!
author: Jeff J.

description:
Can't say enough about the staff and service we received, particularly on such short notice. Even though the restaurant was very busy on a weekend they were able to put together a great evening for us and we were a large group.   Everyone enjoyed their dinner, no complaints were heard.  Would not hesitate going there again whether for a party of 14 or 4.
The kitchen is definitely on top of things...
author: Sylvia V.

description:
Food not great:  Eggplant parmesan.   Not worth $17.00!  I have had better frozen.  This was an overdone and soggy blob sitting all alone in the middle of the plate.  And NO side of vegetables or rice or pasta or salad or anything.  Those who got fish, etc., also at least got vegetables and rice.  
Service so-so.  Waiter haughty.   He didn't come back much.  It took ages to get bread.  Other folks who had come in after us were served first.
Best part:  When it finally arrived - the Bread!  warm, crunchy exterior.
author: K H.

description:
I don't think I'll be eating here again, and with the treatment I both received and witnessed, I advise no one else does either. 

I'm 31 but I look pretty young, so I occasionally receive poor service bc some servers assume I'm not going to tip well (big mistake). I got the feeling my server made this assumption right when he saw me, bc he was very cold from the get go. He remained very cold for the duration of my time there, and after seeing other reviews I'm thinking this is very standard for this place. I was dining alone, so I didn't have to wait extremely long for my food like many others had issue with. However, my server would only drop off what he had for me and then quickly and curtly leave. He never came back to check on anything, I had to flag him down to get refills on my drinks (they charge for soda refills btw, I rarely see that) and he just seemed very apathetic concerning my meal. 

As far as the food, it was fine. I got a very simple plate of spaghetti and a meatball, so it would be hard to mess that up. My issue was the price. I don't remember exactly how much my main dish was, but it was over $20. Considering everything was a la carte, over $20 for a standard spaghetti and meatball plate is pretty high. This place wasn't fine dining or anything that would justify such a high price. Overall, the food itself wasn't really a problem. It was the awful service combined with unjustified high prices. 

Lastly, the most egregious thing that happened didn't even involve myself. I witnessed a server thoroughly berate an older lady. He was so rude to her that I pretty much decided then that I would not be returning. I eat out constantly, and I have had many bad experiences, but I've never witnessed something as despicable as this. No matter the circumstance, a server should never raise his voice to a customer. 

I have heard about this place for a long time, it's supposed to be a real throwback as well as a treasured restaurant in the sunset. I talked to a friend after this (she had recommended it to me) and she said that the ownership had changed somewhat recently. Maybe that is the problem. Anyway, all I can say is I wouldn't visit the Gold Mirror if I were you
author: Patrick J.

description: I've been working as a Realtor in SF and mostly in the Sunset/Parkside for years.  A good friend of mine who I met in 2007 is a regular there and I've been coming here for dinner and drinks on a regular basis ever since.  I've NEVER been disappointed as the food is perfect and most of all, so are the martinis!
author: David K.

description:
Old school, San Francisco and Italian. This isn't some new or hot chef but the type of Italian food that San Francisco used to be known for...it will make you cry it's that good. Truth is, I live close, but only go for special in-the-neighborhood events like back to school nite. 

We always say we should go more often. 

Started with calamari - breaded and grilled with lots of garlic. Not the ubiquitous deep fried version. Magical. Also had the veal scaloppine and cannelloni. Finished with tiramisu. All fantastic. 

The bonus part is that all the food is branded and the origin clearly labeled. Still, after 2 martinis, a bottle of Italian red, a bourbon, tax and 20% tip, I was out less than $200. 

Probably best to watch a Nick and Nora, Bogart or Sinatra movie before going.
author: Scott D.

description:
Went there with an early reservation for Christmas Eve dinner after not having been since a kid.  Homemade lasagna was sooooo delicious.  Filet mignon with baked potato was also very good, meat was cooked to a perfect medium.  Service was attentive.  Went back again for Valentine's Day for the same meal plus the avocado and crab salad, which was well worth the price, chunks of fresh crab meat served with perfectly ripe avocado slices and a homemade thousand island dressing, loved loved loved it.  We don't get to go out much but this restaurant and these dishes are now on our short list.   

As others have mentioned, Gold Mirror is an old school Italian restaurant so adjust your dining and ambiance expectations accordingly.  It can be noisy and crowded and lots of customers seem like they have been eating there with their families for years.  Not the place to go if you are in a hurry or like trendy seen-and-be-seen spots.  But if you are looking for solid-to-exceptional food and stiff drinks definitely give it a try.
author: M M.

description: Never had bad meal here. All staff from busboy to bartender to waiter always take awesome care of you. Food is top notch. Old school dining at its best. Love Gold Mirror.
author: John E.

description: The interior of the restaurant is nostalgic without trying to be, perfectly lit and not too loud.  The calamari was interesting, one of the few times I've had it without any sort of batter, flake, etc.  The quality was there, though I prefer a little crunch to it.  My friends ordered pasta which was delish.  I opted for healthy with the halibut special against my better judgement.  The fish was slimy and the veggies were wilted/wet. We decided to give dessert a go.  My friend ordered cheesecake which the waiter said they were out of.  5 minutes later we overheard someone order cheesecake and get "the last piece" creating an interesting riff between us and the waiter.  My cannoli was great.  I give two stars to places I would not go back to again, but where someone else may have a better experience.
author: Chris K.

description:
I was a little unsure about Gold Mirror when I first walked in with my dad and grandpa... 

The setting: part medieval castle background, part Italian village feeling, part modern bar with fully stocked liquor, and part young hostesses mixed with servers that looked like they've been there since the beginning..

But when my grandpa told me that this place had been around since he was a kid, I was convinced that the food would have to be something special.
