I ordered the veal piccata and it was one of the best dishes I've ever had. It was cooked perfectly and the sauce was delicious. Not too runny, not too thick.. just right. And although the wait time was a little long, the server was extremely polite and attentive to our needs. Places that may not look the best on the inside, but can wow you with their service and dishes. Gold Mirror is one of those places. We all left satisfied and tipped the server very well. 

In the end, looks aren't everything and I would definitely recommend this place to anyone in the area that wants some old school Italian food
author: Sean B.

description: My friend and I both had not dined at Gold Mirror for many years.  We were both pleasantly surprised by the food and service and it left us wondering what took us so long to come back.  The service was wonderful - our friendly waiter would appear at the right moments to take care of us and never hovered too long.  The food was delicious- we shared the calamari olive tepenade salad, my friend had the lamb chops and i had the veal piccata. Outstanding!
author: Lucky D.

description: My wife and I usually come here on our birthdays or anytime we want a special treat.  For years it was our go to place for Thanksgiving for our family, but they stopped opening on Thanksgiving several years ago.  It's a great neighborhood spot for excellent Italian food served in a classic San Francisco setting.  A bit pricey to us, but then the food is top notch.  The sauces and flavors are special.  We always start with the antipasto.  Love it.  Usually order the veal or chicken or seafood.  We did have one down day in November when my wife's prawns didn't taste quite right, but that maybe was just an off night as two times since we have been there and were very pleased.  It's a real classic.  I highly recommend for a special meal or a romantic dinner.  Not a place to go if you're in a hurry and probably not ideal for kids.
author: Bob S.

description: Of course I'm partial to the Gold Mirror, been coming here since the 70's as a kid with my parents.  This latest incarnation has given new life to a funky old place and turned it into a fave. New and old menu items deliciously prepared.  Fish and pasta are my favorites.  Easy to get a table or sit at the bar for a drink and a bite.
author: Stef G.

description:
I have noticed the not so good reviews, but I am a fan.

Sometimes old school Italian American food joints can churn out food that is really sub par with side dishes that are always an afterthought.  Not so at the Gold Mirror.  The chefs take great interest in making sure that the rice and vegetables that accompany each entree are not only prepared perfectly, but taste frickin really good as well.

Standouts: all pasta (homemade) and veal dishes, fried calamari, lasagna- best in SF

Love the old school bar that serves complimentary soft cheddar cheese and ritz crackers!

The vibe is def. old school Italian whose patrons are mostly between 60's-80's, but I, unlike many a snobby San Franciscan restaurant patron, don't mind dinning with octogenarians.
author: Edmond S.

description: Came here with kids and friends.  We've lived in the neighborhood for more than 16 years and were always curious about this place.  Looks like the kind of place you see in a mob movie.  The décor is kind of old school and would fit in the movie, which makes it kind of fun.  It is definitely an old school Italian restaurant, the kind that you would find in North Beach, and the food is equal to that in North Beach as well.  Everyone was very happy with their food, everything was delicious.  One in our group ordered the calamari and loved it.  Veal parm and chicken alla Romana were excellent.  The waiters and staff were so wonderful to the kids.  The only complaint was that we had reservations for 7pm and didnt get seated until after 7:30.
author: Steven B.

description: To me personally, It is like a cozy  Westlake Joes. Old school signage, old school tables and chairs (or maybe just old, but I'm not complaining), old school bar, not a bunch of tvs, and best of all pretty dam good fresh Italian food. The service is great, and the prices are on par with what you would expect.
author: Mina S.

description: Everything is very good.  The petrale soul is excellent, the calamari faux abalone was very good.  Both portions enough to take home.  Still the place to go in the Sunset for fish!
author: J K.

description: We've  been going to the Gold Mirror for years, and consider it to be the top Italian restaurant in the Sunset District.  In the past few years, the chefs have added innovative, delicious, & seasonal daily selections to the regular menu.  The Gold Mirror's cuisine is consistent which we believe is an important element when dining out.  Our favorites include any of the pastas, my favorite is the house made ravioli ; Chicken Cacciatore, Calamari (appetizer and the entrée), Petrale Sole, house salad is basic but good as is the Minestrone, and the specials vary but are definitely worth trying.  Just for the record, this is not a pizza place - it's a very nice restaurant!
author: Sidney D.

description:
IT GREAT TO GET A CHANCE TO VISIT OTHER RESTAURANTS!

As silly as it sounds, we came back again and this time made reservations for a 5:45 seating. Called in and no problem. GREAT, we'll get a nice meal served in plenty of time. The four of us get there at 5:45 and the nice hostess says it will be a few minutes. Well, the few minutes rolled into 15 minutes so I inquired . . . actually how long will it be before we're seated: in about 45 minutes.  So let's see: 5:45 really meant 6:45.  I said we had reservations and told that they have no seating limit policy.  In other words, if a dozen people made reservations for a 5:45 seating, you'll get the reservation. No problem. You just wont get a table.

Also noting that in 15 minutes standing around, little food was coming out of the kitchen, the full dining room was feasting on bread and water.  It looked like very person there between 5 and 5:30. Full room and no food.  Such a treat!  

With a little Yelping, we decided to head to Irving street and found the very nice Chabaa Thai restaurant. Intimate, family run and wonderful Thai food.  

I have several suggestions:  1) have an open bar for those of us waiting with complimentary wine and drinks, or consider serving complimentary "waiting wine" when people are seated and waiting.  This will help the management figure out that you'd only make so many reservations within a certain amount of time.  2) Since you're waiting, why not check out the other restaurants in the Yelp app.  That's how we found Chabaa Thai.  3) If you're brave enough to wait the hour or so feasting on bread and water, enjoy!  Even the guys at Alcatraz got faster service.
author: Stefan L.

description:
My husband and I love Italian food, so we've been intending to check out this restaurant for a long time since it's right in our neighborhood. Unfortunately, it was not worth the wait.

The service at the restaurant was really poor. Neither my husband nor I were greeted when we came in separately; we finally talked to the bartender who informed a waiter that we had a reservation. After we were seated and greeted by our waiter, we asked for a couple minutes to look over the menu. Unfortunately, "a couple minutes" translated to at least fifteen, and although we saw our waiter serve other tables, he did not come back to check on us for some time.

Overall, we found the waiter's attitude somewhat strange. He would inch to the table with a dessert menu but not say anything, as though he were waiting for us to make the first move. Overall, we felt like we were outsiders at the restaurant, as if we didn't know the trick for ordering or getting good service there.

The food itself was good, but not better than our favorite Italian restaurants in town. My husband got the prosciutto tortellini, which was delicious but came in a very small portion, and I got the veal scallopini, which was good and adequately portioned. I ordered an incredibly disappointing glass of Moscato D'asti; where I've been served a wineglass at other restaurants, here I was served the equivalent of a double-shot and charged $8. And even though I rarely leave a restaurant without at least looking at the dessert menu, we ended up going without because we were both itching to leave.

As for the interior, a lot of people have been complimentary, but I didn't think it was anything beyond your typical Italian restaurant, Tuscan-style decor. One feature we didn't like was that as you enter the outer door, you're immediately hit with a curtain that you have to pass through to get to the restaurant. We weren't initially sure if the the restaurant was even open, and this contributed to the "unwelcome" vibe we felt overall.
author: Kristen L.

description: I have been here two times and both were amazing visits. The place doesn't look like much from the outside but once you get in it's striking. The decor is what I would feel like old world Italy and it causes you to look around constantly. Since my fiancé is Italian her family orders a lot of apps and pastas to share which is the way to do it. The staff here is also very friendly and warm. We had a lot of people so, with a big table orders could go to the wrong person but our server was right on point. Both times I have had the veal cannelloni and it's unbelievable. This place was my first cannoli which I thought was unreal and with the approval of my fiancé and her parents from New York originally I think that speaks for itself. Can't wait to go back!
author: Chris G.

description: We came here for a date night and I have to say, the décor definitely takes me back. But that's not what matters, it's the food that matters and I think that everything was on point. My fiance and I had the caprese salad and opted to have some specials of the day. From the squid ink pasta to the stuffed calamari, everything was superb.
author: Shauna S.

description: had dinner at this neighborhood Italian restaurant last night with friends, service was great, cant remember the servers name, but she was a very nice young lady from Milan Italy.  The food was all cooked perfectly.  we all enjoyed our meals very much.  i have also been here for lunch a few times, and the food and service is always great.
author: steve z.

description: The first thing that struck me about Gold Mirror is the decor.  If Tony Soprano and Donatella Versace were to get busy, they would probably choose the GM.  It's dark and over the top Cinderella's Castle meets the Godfather mansion.  The bartenders are generous pourers--my Dirty Goose practically overflowed from the glass and they are strong and stiff and dirtier than a stripper pole.  We commandeered the room upstairs for our 28th year 8th grade reunion (who DOES that?) but it was a fun time.  Them stairs are a little hard to negotiate though after the dirty martinis, so just be warned.  The prime rib was flavorful, a tad on the salty side and gigantic--almost covered the whole plate.  Loved this place more for the memories I shared and recreated with old friends.   Parking is challenging but not impossible.
author: Joc V.

description:
Oh Mama Mia... it's abbondanza!!!  Ok... so an earlier reviewer described this restaurant as "medieval times meets Beauty and the Beast meets cocktail lounge and that is what I love about this old establishment.  A bit dark and cavernous, and the waiters dress formally.   The menu is Classic.. with your typical antipasto, eggplant parmesan, lasagna... all the things your Itallian grandma would expect in such a place.  The selections were tasty and we were delighted!  

My husband is half-Italian, from Philadelphia, and this is the kind of Italian restaurant he grew up with.  He had a huge smile on his face the entire time.  It was Father's Day, and this couldn't have been a better choice for a Father's Day dinner....

And don't leave without ordering dessert!   Try the zabaglione.... egg yolks, sugar and Marsala wine make for the perfect Italian custard.  

We live in the East Bay, but a trip to Gold Mirror is worth the drive... down memory lane.

"Grazie" Gold Mirror.... "Grazie"...
author: Doris D.

description:
Food was just ok. I had the filet medallion and my husband had the spaghetti, both left something to be desired.

Service was horrible. Waiters were slow and unattentive. We had to go up to the host to ask for our bill and the restaurant was only half full.

Won't be returning.
author: Arika B.

description: I have been coming to Gold Mirror for years with my family and I have always had good service and very good food. If you have time and are looking for a nice place to have a good meal than please give Gold Mirror a try. You will not be disappointed.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I should have heeded the warnings. Made reservations, then waited five minutes for someone to acknowledge my wife and I standing at the front (the only two people waiting for a table). It wasn't that busy, and the service was severely lacking. Our waiter walked up in black tie, didn't even greet us, just stood there and waited for us to order. The food was decent, but I didn't feel like it remotely overcame the poor service. It tasted similar to family style Italian food that you can get just about anywhere, nothing close to what we paid. 

We even read the yelp reviews and were really ready to be forgiving, and by no means are we fancy, high-maintenance people. The service was really that bad. Avoid.
author: Darren W.

description:
As a native San Franciscan, I've gotten quite spoiled by the diversity in this city.  There are so many choices in restaurants but I've always been curious about The Gold Mirror.  For many years, I kept passing by it when taking the L-Taraval on the way to work.  

There have been a number of closures of my favorite dine-in restaurants so my husband and I made our way here on an impromptu date night.

Let me just say that the decor is very old-school yet doesn't look outdated or drab.  When I walked in, I was greeted very warmly by the hostess.  Considering we hadn't bothered to dress up, I wasn't sure what kind of reception we would experience.  It did not faze her one bit.

In fact, my husband and I were seated immediately at a good table.  From what I can tell, the set up of the room is a little tight at the center but at the perimeter, you won't get jostled or feel like you're in the way.

Our server was the older of the two that seemed to be responsible for the floor. He also did not seemed fazed by our casual attire even though everyone around us was fairly dressed up.  He allowed us ample time to review the regular and special menu.  He didn't try to upsell us and in fact, only asked if we wanted wine to pair with our meal.  He didn't press us after we said no.

We ordered:

Garlic Fried South American Prawns  $15

Homemade Prosciutto Tortellini "stuffed with San Daniele prosciutto in a cream sauce"  $17

Veal Milanese "breaded cutlet fried in olive oil with small Sicilian capers, fresh sage, Gilroy garlic, lemon, and chardonnay served with rice and vegetables"  $20

Cheesecake "della Nonna topped with a fresh berry sauce"  $7

The prawns were flavored quite well and could have probably been taken off the burner a bit earlier.  They were on the edge of being too dry but were very tasty.

The homemade prosciutto tortellini was my favorite item in this sitting.  I normally do not like cured meats but something about this called my name.  I'm glad I listened.  Not one hint of gristle, which is something that grosses me out when I find it, and the prosciutto was not overbearingly salty like it can tend to be.  Most of the time, I do not finish my meal but this was just the right amount and every morsel was delightful. In fact, I kept dipping my bread into the extra cream sauce that remained after eating the tortellini.  

(By the way, that is some of the best complimentary bread I have been offered in a long time.)

My husband was not as impressed with the veal milanese.  He wasn't disappointed, just not impressed.  It was not what he was expecting but it wasn't bad.  It was "nothing to write home about".  The meat portion was sufficient but he felt that there could have been more vegetables on the plate or a hint of pasta to go with it to make it more substantial.  

Now the cheesecake, we both loved.  It was definitely made with cream cheese but it was not heavy.  It was very fluffy and not to sweet, which is perfect for us.

Most of all, as a person of color who often finds myself being treated as 'less than' by the people who are there to serve me,  I was extremely impressed that the staff who I encountered were all very classy and friendly.

There is a TV at the bar and they do play music but the volume is kept low-key.  It is one of the few places where my husband and I have not had to shout over the table in order to be heard.

While I would not bring babies or children who are hard to keep contained to this restaurant, this is a good place to start if you are looking to teach your older children proper table etiquette.

If you look up, you will see the Gold Mirror that is the restaurant's namesake.

When I get a moment this weekend, I will try to post photos.
author: Gabriela S.

description:
This restaurant was an incredible pleasant surprise. Oscar war excellent! Cannelloni... I have been in search of the perfect crepé cannelloni for years. This place almost rivals my cannelloni .Light. Fluffy. Flavorful. Incredible.
Fantastic service, and food!
As one who's been around the world a bit, I highly respect this place. It needs to be discovered by you!
author: Javier A.

description:
Had a lovely evening at the Gold Mirror restaurant for my brother-in-law's rehearsal dinner. We were seated in the upstairs private space overlooking the main dining room and had a great time. 

Food:
The bride and groom ordered a banquet menu for us. We enjoyed an antipasto plate, penne with Bolognese sauce, a house salad, and my entrée was probably the best prime rib I'd ever had. There were lots of choices of entrées, from salmon, eggplant Parmesan, veal Parmesan, and prime rib. From the food we tasted, I would definitely come back and try more of the menu items. We couldn't stick around for dessert and coffee, unfortunately, but I know that would have been a fantastic end to the meal. 

Service:
Outstanding.  We had one server taking care of us all night and he was fantastic. He kept up with all of our requests and nothing seems to faze him. This was pretty impressive given we had a party of about 22 people.  We really felt like we were being well taken care of and part of the Gold  Mirror family.

Vibe:
Comfortable and informal but also intimate even with a large group. Like you are in someone's home, but better. I'd probably enjoy sitting at the downstairs bar and could probably do it for hours. A great place to spend an evening. 

Family-friendly:
We didn't have the children with us for this rehearsal dinner, but I would definitely bring my children here.  I know we would be looked after very well and have a nice evening, even with the pesky kids!

Summary:
I don't award five stars for places that I have only visited once, but I know that when I come back here again I will be able to award that fifth star. I am sure that we would have a great evening here whether we brought the kids or not and it probably doesn't matter what we order because everyone in our party enjoyed their food and I would even trust the staff to choose my meal for me. Check out Gold Mirror and mangia!
author: Aneesh B.

description:
Went here on a whim with my parents and grandma (who is old-school Italian, and native San Franciscan).  Called ahead on a Friday night and reserved our table. Greeted warmly and seated promptly, and got warm bread and water. So far so good.

The decor, though. I know they just remodeled, but holy cannoli, it is strange. Medieval Times meets Beauty and the Beast meets cocktail lounge?

Calamari appetizer was very good -- sauteed rather than breaded and fried, and it was tasty and tender and the garlicky olive oil was  nice with bread.

Entrees arrived a little while after the appetizer was cleared. I ordered meat ravioli with mushroom-tomato sauce: very good! I was thoroughly impressed. Probably about 5 large (palm-sized?) ravioli with very flavorful meat filling, and the pasta was nicely robust - not mushy or overcooked, very al dente.  The sauce was full of mushrooms and very tasty, and a nice balance of sauce to ravioli.  Mom ordered the cannelloni, which were kind of undramatic (surprising, since it's what the restaurant is known for) -- they were two logs of rolled pasta covered in a red and white sauce, on a shallow plate, no garnish or anything. The ravioli at least had a sprinkle of parsley on top. But she said it was good, and filling too. Dad had veal piccata, grandma had veal marsala I think. Both said they were good, looked like a nice plate of food. 

Dessert was the Italian cream cake and the chilled zabaglione. Both good, very traditional.  The cream cake was like something you'd get at Dianda's, very authentically Italian-American. Rum, cream, sponge cake, something crunchy on the outside.

All in all, don't be scared of the frightened and negative Yelp reviews of this place. Just order what makes sense in a restaurant like this: something Italian-American, classic and uncomplicated, and go back in time a little bit. Not all the way to the Renaissance, as the decor suggests you do, but, you know.
author: Amanda M.

description: This place is a classic old school Italian restaurant.  It has all of the classic pasta, seafood, veal, and appetizers you would expect.  Nothing cutting edge here but everything is well prepared and delicious.  Service can be a little slow- especially if you are in a large party.
author: John S.

description:
2 stars service
3 stars for food

Very crowded ...service is slow .  Waiter is not attentive to details.  Bit this place has a following and people tolerate it.  Haha
author: Darlene H.

description:
Went to the Gold Mirror simply because it was a block from where we were. A bit apprehensive because part of the neon sign was not functioning which made it look run down. It was a week night and we were seated immediately. A look around at the decor was a second warning. A weird combo of medieval meets New Jersey Italian. 

However, the service was excellent and the waiter was patient as we drank and waited for a friend. When he finally showed up we ordered and had time to catch up as the appetizers arrived. All of the warnings were forgotten as we ate. When the main courses arrived all discussion stopped as we dug in. The food was that good.

GM is very old school. The waiter didn't tell us his name or try to be our friend. The rhythm was neither hurried nor plodding. The staff obviously was letting us set the pace. Best of all, it was quiet without being dead. We were able to talk comfortably unlike so many restaurants that want a loud buzz.

The GM is the place to go if you're in the neighborhood and want really good food in a traditional atmosphere.
author: J. B.

description:
My favorite Italian place in SF. It can't be beat. Everytime I go, I try and angle for the veal ravioli, an antipasti dish, and (my favorite dessert of all time) some zabaglione. 

However, this past time we (the family; we always hit Gold Mirror as an unstoppable family force) got the prix fixe. It was amazing. It came with some delicious mozzerella fig salad with a light balsamic and proscuitto, some other amazing appetizer I can't currently recall because the first was so delicious, and a lobster and scallop linguini. Words can't even describe.

Afterwards, not one to let my stomach being painfully full to dictate whether I am going to eat or not, we still got the zabaglione--- the most delicious whipped, warm treat anyone can ask for. 

Sure, it's a bit pricey. But hey, it's worth it. The servers are beyond attentive, and the chef is always genuinely flattered by compliments.

Drinks are good (9/10) and the only thing I would minus maybe half a point on is the new decor. Seriously. It's a little cheeseball. But oh so easy to overlook once the food is set in front of you. GO!
author: Grace A.

description: One word. Amazing! This place should be 5 out of 5. Must go for the calamari to start! The staff and food are what make this restaurant tick. Oh, and the drinks! Check it out ASAP.
author: Alex R.

description: Best Italian food in the city. Been going here since I was born. Many birthdays and family parties were had here. Great to see the food has not changed since Giuseppe's sons have taken over. They are doing a fantastic job!! Keep up the great work!
author: Nicholas B.

description:
man just punch me in the fucking face...

I should give myself one star for not checking Yelp on this place.n  That's how much I hate Yelp, but in this restaurants case 3.5 Stars way more than it deserves.

First let me say my waiter was one of the worst waiters I have even encountered.  He made my supposedly nice dinner date into a infuriating as i watched him the whole time.  Service yeah right hell f'in no.

Ok the food again punch me in the fucking face for ordering a Prime Rib at a Italian Joint.  $34 bucks for what you would call a Tiny Cut at HOPR.  Did you throw it in the micorwave, cuz that shit was disgusting!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I only will say one good thing is that the spaghetti and meatballs was actual pretty good.

Now back to my bitching,  on top of all that BS the food took forever.  What more can go wrong?  I kept looking back at the kitchen and they saw me but no one even came over to even say a damn word.

Note to self, once you see the special entrees printed on a piece of white paper get the hell out of there.

Oh and to the waiter don't be mad at your tip. Didn't even deserve that much.  I wold have gotten better service at a buffet!
author: King L.

description: We made a reservation, and shoved our way in to a mob scene where no one seemed to be monitoring the huge crowd waiting to be seated.  Finally we snagged an employee who said "just a minute".  Ten minutes later, we managed to make it to the bar, only to be told by the bartender, "I'm too busy to make a drink".  Period. Needless to say, we left. To paraphrase Seinfeld, "Anyone can TAKE a reservation...". Too bad.  I live in the neighborhood and have good memories of this place from years ago.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I was very pleasantly surprised at this place. I'd always wondered what it must be like and it totally lived up to my expectations.

The decor is super old school red sauce Italian, with waiters in tuxedos and a mezzanine that looks like it's rented out for parties or weddings.

Bread was fresh and nicely crusty, the glass of chianti I ordered (I didn't even look at the wine list to be honest) was nice and the waiter was helpful and charming.

Two of us ordered the "Five Hour Lamb Ragu with home made bucatini." I love bucatini and it was delicious. The sauce was nice  and not heavy and the lamb (clearly a long cooked tough cut like a shoulder) was delicious and very flavorful. My caesar salad was also very nice, but the croutons were a bit on the hard side and there were only three of them. A small quibble.

My only complaint was that I felt like the prices were a bit on the high side ($22 for the bucatini) and the service was a bit slow. We decided that they want you to linger and make it an evening, so we just went with that and enjoyed ourselves.
author: Mike F.

description:
Not worth the price! It is substandard Italian old school over salted and the wine is overpriced. Sadly enough the only Italian place this side of the city. I'd say 
Olive Garden is better, and that's sad!
author: Joseph H.

description:
Look, the pasta was good, but when our waiter returned and asked, "How's everything?  Delicious?" I really wanted to reply, "Yes, but not $18.00 delicious."

Very expensive, and you aren't getting much bang for your buck.  I think this restaurant is operating off of an old paradigm, as evidenced by the fact I was the only customer in their under 70.

Our service was also very lackluster.  They took forever to take our order (it was NOT crowded), were lethargic in bringing us our bread and water (mmm...Safeway SELECT), and then forgot to bring us our soup and just went right to the main entree.  

Also, considering I'm paying ten dollars for a glass of wine that I know for a fact costs ten dollars PER BOTTLE, the least you could do is put it in proper stemware! This is like a plastic play-cup, ridiculous.  Serve me wine in a wine glass, Mr. Fancy Pants Restaurant.  Also, pour me an actual glass of wine instead of this tiny quarter-glass pour.  Cheapskates. I'm paying enough.

The food was....good.  Not worth the sack of gold nuggets I had to pay to get it.
author: Brian L.

description:
For the person who ripped the Gold Mirror a new one...
If you can't even spell the name of the street they're located on, I'd say it's safe to say no one should listen to your opinion.
It's Taraval,  BTW!
I've taken several people to the Gold Mirror.
Everyone loves it and wants to go back when they return on future visits.
The last time I went I had the most delicious Sea Bass I've ever had and my friend had the lamb chop which he so graciously let me taste; oh my goodness.  I can't wait to go back and order the lamb chop myself.  As it happens, I have guests from out of town tonight.  One has experienced the Gold Mirror during her last visit and asked if we can go back... of course we can!!!
I love, love, love the place.  The only reason I gave it a 4 is because at times the servers come across a bit arrogant.  However, on the other hand, most speak at least two languages (Italian and English) so... they've kinda' earned the right ;)
See you tonight!
author: Donna L.

description: We had  a party of five for dinner.  The waiter takes our order without writing it down.  Of course it gets screwed up.  We order two soups and only one came.  Four orders arrived and the fifth was missing.  Took an hour for the food to arrive.  Hour fifteen for the fifth order.  Fettuccini was ok, calamari ok, ravioli and Pork chops descent.
author: Garret T.

description: I remember The Gold Mirror as a child the dinners were a five course meal at that time my parents knew the Owner and his family. I remember his name was Mike. I contnued to go there thru high school somtetimes without my parents Mike knew me by name he used to tease me about my boyfriends saying he was going to tell my parents (he never did) It was like a second home for me to get  wonderful food for a reasonable price. It has been 40 years since I have been there .We went for my mothers 90th Birthday for a party of 20. I was very disappointed to say the least. The Caprese salad was good but then reality set in.The veal picata was like eating tasteless leather. My husband has the minerstrone which needed seasoning. His fish was like eating a tastless piece of rubber. The service from the waiters was good they were attentive and friendly. Hence the two stars. Most of the guests were dissatisfied with the meal. We did not have deesert there. Granted we had a large party but we made reservations more than a week in advance.  So I figured we would have a good experience ( Not so much) Thought the meal was overpriced. My husband and I will not be going back there. I just have the warm homey memories left of the yesteryear  and I am good with that!!!!!
author: Beth A. O.

description:
Had a wonderful dinner last night. The food was spectacular. Very light for Italian food. Had one of the daily specials which was a seafood pasta dish. Very fresh and lovely! 

I would give them a better score, but our waiter was rude and aloof. I won't completely rule them out because of one waiter... If I go again and am treated the same... I won't go back. But, the food was very good. The decor was okay... Not too dark like a lot of Italian restaurants... Let's hope he was having a bad day...
author: Kimberly R.

description:
Very, very good traditional Italian spot in the Outer Sunset that'll make you feel like "La Famiglia."

I sampled across the menu and shared an outstanding appetizer of calamari (sauteed yet crunchy with lots of parsley); veal piccata and home-made tortellini stuffed with prosciutto and cream cheese in a "light" cream sauce.

No, the cream sauce was **not** light but wow, did it make that entree spectacularly decadent. The veal was a touch on the salty side (and I like salt) so if you're not inclined, ask them to season accordingly.

The atmosphere was definitely old-school Italian and I liked it. The waitstaff was attentive and warm.

If you're in the Taraval corridor, or like me a few miles away from it, Gold Mirror is worth the trip.

I would come here for a romantic table for two, a big party with family or friends or solo for lunch.

I recommend!
author: Jennifer O.

description: We eat there regularly. We generally can get right in without a reservation. Today we will drop in for lunch. I love the veal piccatta. The salads and appetizers are great. We have always had good service. Our parents are generally with us and sometime we bring some grandkids and great grand children. It is traditional American Italian, with a modern flair. Cloth table cloths, napkins, and we love it. It can get busy, but lunch is usually not a problem. Have not held an event there, but can imagine it is a drain on resources.
author: Norman F.

description:
Sometimes nostalgia begets memories. I remember coming to the Gold Mirror when I was in middle school. I thought it was so fancy at the time and it's where I first learned about prosciutto and melon. It seemed like such a strange combo for my 13-year-old self and years later, it's still on the menu. 

Fast forward to 2012 and the Gold Mirror no longer feels fancy to me. The ravioli was good and although old school melon and prosciutto is still on the menu, it is joined by a new school burrata appetizer. Baskets of warm bread and carby pasta in an old school atmosphere makes Gold Mirror just as fun as I remember.
author: Lee H.

description:
You will not get better value for your dollar than this old fashioned Italian Restaurant.  I happen to love it.  I live in Marin otherwise I would be there every week.  I love the lasagne, cannelloni, spaghetti and meatballs, salmon and steak.  Their desserts are fantastic.  The cheesecake della nona is my favorite.
  I like the fact that I can walk in and get a table right away.  The service is always first rate. It is not in or trendy but if the food is your main focus you have to go out to the avenues and see what I mean.  You will not be sorry.  They also have a full bar.  It's the kind of bar that looks like the " rat pack " is going to walk in any minute. The waiters also wear jackets at night.  It is really the best.

Sandy
author: Sandy R.

description:
So we had a Christmas party here recently and several of us walked away somewhat disappointed with the meal.

First of all, this joint is a local favorite and could probably be compared to Marcello's a few blocks down the street.  Good little family owned joint serving up good food in a nice setting BUT they really dropped the ball on us the other night and here's why:

1- Appetizers were crap in both quality and selection.  Surely they could have done better than the assortment of canned peppers, cappocola, olives and salami.

2- Although my entree (veal parmigiana) was good, my colleague received his eggplant parmigiana almost 10 minutes after everybody else with no accompaniment!!  Not even a little scoop of rice, something that would have cost the house about 2 cents.  I actually had to ask one of the waiters to just bring him and his wife a plate as a favor to me.

3- Dessert was a measly little scoop of artificially flavored vanilla ice cream with a stale lady finger on the side.  Surely they could have done a little better than that.  Why not wow all of us with a nice little square of tiramisu.  Yes, it would have cost the house a bit more but what a way to end a meal and impress 50 potential new customers.

Overall, we had a great time but the decision has already been made not to return next year due to the above and a few other minor things that just added up.  In the end, the house made a very tidy profit from this party but in the long run, they blew it.

It will be a while before I return.  In the meantime, we'll just pop into Marcello's for our pasta e vino.
author: Anthony D.

description:
it's been awhile since i've visted GM...but from what I remember as a child, their Linguini with white clam sauce were to die for!!  Unlike Buca, this place actually has taste to their linguini plates (sorry Buca lovers!!) Nice big portion and the servers are very nice too.

The signature Mirror hanging on the wall...reminds me of Disneyland Haunted house. 

Must go back soon!!
author: Vee V.

description: Fantastic food served here and it was the best homemade cannelloni I have had since Northern Italy.
author: Judy M.

description: My wife and I had lunch yesterday. We had Homemade Cannelloni stuffed with veal  and and ricotta cheese served with red and white sauces as well veal scaloppini served with a marsala mushroom sauce. The veal was extremely tender but the sauces were completely without taste - there were no discernible spices.  It seemed a shame to waste such high quality veal with such poor sauces. Based upon the previous good reviews, we assume that there was a serious kitchen problem on the day of our visit but the experience was so poor that we won't chance another lunch at the Gold Mirror.
author: Phil L.

description: The food was amazing! My mom had the eggplant parmagian, dad got the spaghetti & clams bordelaisse, and I got the veal parmagiani. The eggplant was my favorite out of all them, but the other two were still really good. We got an Italian cream cake and a chilled zabaglione for dessert and they were so delicious! Definitely would come back again. Also, the inside looks really cool! Unexpected from what it looks like outside
author: Holly P.

description:
We went there tonight (Wednesday) at around 7:30.  It was not busy so we were quickly seated.  The decor is old-fashioned yet pleasant.  The service was good and prompt, except for some reason, the ravioli took a while to prepare.  It was odd because during the course of the meal, the two of us were the only new patrons.  

We ordered two appetizers from the specials menu, I wasn't sure what to expect but they tasted decent but not spectacular.  We shared one entree, the ravioli, which was quite tasty.

Overall, I think the dishes are too expensive for what they are.  It does not offer good value for the money.
author: William L.

description:
This was a fairly important dinner tonight. Dining with our son's girlfriend's parents in SF   ( OK there may be a long term relationship down the road for all of us) ,
the Gold Mirror delivered on a very nice dining experience for us. 

I'm not one to chronicle everyone's entree  and appetizer but I can say that the sautéed calamari was terrific and personally I have been in search of an old school Caesar salad for a while, and this comes pretty close. 

All seven of us at the table were very happy with their entree as well. I will order Veal Parmesan whenever it's  offered and tonight it was delicious. The chicken and Petrale Sole entrees were wonderful also. 

The elephant in the room here is timeliness 
 of this restaurant. 

Make no mistake, the decor may not fit the cookie cutter new top 50 hot spot Tapas restaurants in SF , but there is a charm to the old school Italian neighborhood establishment that we are dangerously close to losing forever. 

My personal thanks to Michael Krasny on NPR for mentioning this restaurant. (Plz forgive if I have misspelled your name).

This is a treasure to be preserved
author: Kevin G.

description: We had dinner last Saturday here and it was great! Went early (right after they opened) and got seated immediately. The service was excellent and super attentive. The food was even better! I strongly suggest the calamari appetizer.  I have never had it better anywhere else. The poached salmon was also amazing. All in all a perfect evening. I would suggest reservations if you plan on going later in the evening.
author: Stu H.

description: This place is just ok. I come here once a year for a birthday and consistently get a mediocre meal.
author: Brian S.

description: Love love love this place!  The ambience is weird and charming.  The food is off the charts good.  This restaurant is one of those rare little finds that once found, you will keep coming back for the rest of your life.  Our waiter, Mark, is the best.  He is friendly, but not overly-friendly.  He makes honest recommendations and hasn't steered me wrong.  The lasagna and eggplant Parmesan are the best I've ever had.  This place is authentic as it gets and is a fantastic value in today's world.
author: Teresa S.

description: This restaurant is great and the food is superb.The veal scalapini is awesome and has great flavor.It is one of the best Ive tasted .It has a lot of sauce and mushrooms and the veal is thin and not too thick and tender.You can get it with rice or potatoes.This is really the best veal scalapini in town..I know because Ive tasted them all.The restaurant also ha great canneloni and many other tastey dishes..the chief really knows what hes doing.The atmoshpere is cozy and Italian with a great retro bar that has a retro liting ...makes you feel like you are in 1950s.The staff is friendly and music good with great Italian music in the Sinatra mood.All in all this restaurant is a must see nestled in the San Francisco avenues.
author: Janet D.

description: We just had a birthday party with 20 guests. I read some bad reviews and was a bit concerned about having my father's birthday party here. However, nothing of the bad things described in those reviews was true in our case. Staff and the owner were super nice and accommodating, super attentive, so patient with us, very polite! The food arrived at the same time for all of the guests. Guests enjoyed the food. We had such a great time and would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Kate B.

description: Amazing veal picata! Great restaurant. A step back in time. Lots of old school native San Franciscans!
author: Kelly M.

description:
I used to live in the neighborhood and had my first stop back in a couple years when I was passing through SF. 

 Had two suppers there and they were better than I remember.  Chef Domenico and his brother Chef Roberto have taken the Gold Mirror to the next level.  

The daily specials menu, with fresh local ingredients is outstanding.  I had the artichoke appetizer and it was excellent as was the veal de Parma.  Also had the fettuccine with crab one night and a bowl of the Tuscan tripe.  Awesome food.

The best was yet to come.  I was traveling back to Portland the next morning and Chef Domenico made a couple of orders of the Veal Cannelloni and froze it overnight, ready to cook when I got home.

I drove that Cannelloni 600 miles, and the next evening had a great meal.  I would love to see them sell some of their great pasta dishes like the Cannelloni and the lasagna where I could get it at the market locally.  I'd buy it!

Great job guys,  the Gold Mirror is one of the things I miss about living in San Francisco (that and going to the ballpark to see the Giants or to the Stick to see the 49ers.)  

Hopefully it won't be a few years before I get back to SF for some great home cooked, authentic Italian neighborhood restaurant food!
author: Jerry C.

description: We dropped into this place on a whim, just being tourists. I yelped after sitting down and saw a bunch of negative reviews. We decided to stay and couldn't have been any happier. It was early evening and we were in t-shirts and shorts, the wait staff were wearing tuxedos. Yeah its old school but what an outstanding place to eat. The food was remarkable, all 6 of us ate different meals and there wasn't a bite left anywhere. Absolutely the best zabaglione anywhere. I could go on about each meal but suffice to say I wish this restaurant was in my hometown. Moderate priced for upscale dining, the staff including the owner were friendly efficient and a lot of fun. Anyone who had a bad experience here brought that joss with them. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Doug J.

description:
Went there with a buddy about six years ago and had a very good gentlemen's meal with martinis, red meat, pasta, the usual.  Went there a couple of weeks ago with a big group including some out of towners, and the staff took very good care of us.  Everyone liked their food, and my chops were cooked to perfection and done up in a nice marsala (or sherry or whatever wine) sauce.   Perfectly good green beans and potato chunks - delicious!  The sangiovese at $30 a pop was no screaming deal, but everyone enjoyed it (lots of it for some of us).

To those people who complain that it's too "old school" , I say this:  lose the jeans and t-shirt and dress up just a little for Chrissakes!  Yea, it's old school and the waiters look and act respectable.  Got a problem with that?  I'm sure they can find a garbage truck to stuff you in.

To those who say it''s  too expensive, I ask you this:  can you read a menu?  Practically every restaurant in town posts a menu in the window and those that don't will be happy to let you browse one before you get seated.   If you can't afford it, don't eat there - duh!  There are plenty of decent, inexpensive places within two blocks of the GM where you can walk right in and get fed for $15 - $20 bucks.   So stop whining, cheapskates!

To the nut job who laced his review with F-bombs, let's just say your review says more about you than it does about the GM.  Now go home - I hear your mommy calling.

So I have to ask my self the rhetorical question - after living in the neighborhood since 1997, how come I've only been here twice?  Good question!  Need to go back and have a drink at the bar before dinner.

Four stars, with a fifth star added to balance out the crackpots who give it a one star rating.
author: Arnold T.

description:
How does this restaurant survive? Food is mediocre yet expensive. Decor is old and grungy in some sort of medieval setting. I was very disappointed in the small portions as well. 
Service is attentive, though we were only one of the few customers. All that I recommend is for the menu to be updated, prices lowered, and a remodel from top to bottom.
author: Denise W.

description: This is one of the best places to get quality Italian food in the Parkside neighborhood.  In my opinion if I had to choose between here or Marchello's down the road... I would choose this place.  Every time I come here for dinner I leave impressed.  They know what they are doing.  See for yourself!
author: Micaela M.

description: Every time we've come here, we've had wonderful service -- the sweetest, kindest people -- and the tastiest food. The menu is a teeny bit pricey but I'd gladly pay that for the experience!
author: Jaz S.

description:
Love, Love, Love.
I would have to say this is one of the best Italian restaurants in the city! My grandparents have been dinning here for over 10 years! It's so freakin good!  The food is a little pricey but its well worth it. I always get the same thing but I have tried many many things on the menu, each as delicious as the next. I always get the seafood pasta with extra seafood and extra sauce. They will even make it for me even though its not on the menu! The owners are always there and they are super friendly, their two sons are the chefs. Its a family business and you can tell them care about making amazing dishes for people to enjoy. I wish I could eat here everyday!
author: Cristina S.

description:
Being that this restaurant has been in business since the 1940's, we had to check out the Gold Mirror.  As many have pointed out, it's got that old school retro vibe without being a hipster enclave so kudos for that!

There were five of us and while we went over the extensive menu, wine list and full bar options we decided to start with the antipasto appetizer.  The menu suggests this is a dish for two but it nicely started all of us out on a very good meal.  The boyfriend ordered the escargot which was quite tasty...one of my friends that admits she's a picky eater enjoyed it.

With glasses of wine and midori sours in hand, we dived into our main dishes.  I ordered the veal saltinbocca and my boyfriend had the filet mignon...others around the table enjoyed the salmon, stuffed prawns and filet medallions.  We were among friends so were more than happy to try each others dishes...yummy all around!  We were all pretty sated and quite full but that didn't stop us from ordering desserts: zabaione, creme cake, and chocolate filled cannolis.  Wow!

Give this traditional old school place a try.
author: TJ T.

description:
Finely Ine writing a review having gone for dinner there 6 times in the past year!

I think I secretly dint won share this gem with NE one!

It is a bona fide example of true San Francisco family style Italian ristorante.  In a word OSO BUCO.

The food is matched by the sterling service -black jackets and bowties, fast and attentive, and most accommodating.

Final note, one of the few places  that still has Spumoni, excellent Spumoni, on the dessert list. 

N JOY!/  buon apetito!

* All the above has been retracted by reason of INSIPID denial of valid gift coupon, on the grounds that it had "expired".
author: Clifford L.

description: We had a family reunion dinner here this past week and the food was exceptional!! Although our server was not very friendly he was attentive to our needs. The decor although decorated for Halloween did provide the feel of a small well established authentic Italian restaurant.
author: Valerie M.

description:
I just had the best Birthday party in my life at the Gold Mirror. Great service (it's family owned and operated) and the food is fantastic and flavorful. I won't go on and on with all of the details of my experience but if you dig a old school Italian restaurant vibe you will love the way the place looks and feels.
 
                                                                          Molto buono
author: Patches R.

description:
Worst service ever! The server yelled at me "I am a server not a servant" when i asked for dessert wine selections and when instead of a late harvest muscat he brought me champagne! And I tried to politely explain the difference since I am a waiter myself and take pride in profession and my knowledge of wines. That guy is a disgrace! When a manager came out she said that there is nothing she could do, owners are not here right now and she had that horrible guy continue to serve us, she didn't take over, she only asked if she should comp something. She asked!!! I refused and she was more than happy of course.
A completely ruined evening!!!! And not even an apology!!
author: leonid v.

description:
Woah, and by that I mean YUM! 
My friend and I stopped here to eat last night. When we got inside we felt a little under dressed. The restaurant has a rich/ritzy feel to it and such beautiful woodwork and lighting. When we sat down I noticed a couple wearing sweatshirts. I didn't feel so bad wearing my jeans and t-shirt, but I quickly went to the ladies room to fix my hair and make my scarf look neater. 

I had the tortellini and my friend had the veal parmesan. I can't even express it in words how amazing our meals were. I had tasted the veal and it was so tasty. After dinner we had some dessert with our red wine. I'm not sure what our wine was, all I know is that it was red and it went down quite smooth. For dessert I had the ice cream sundae and he had tiramisu. Both were delectable! We finished our night off with a cup of coffee and walked to the car with a fat and sassy smile on our faces. 

This place is tops. Hands down it is the best tasting Italian food I've ever had the pleasure in indulging in.
author: Angie P.

description:
Oh my goodness! This may be my new favorite restaurant. We stumbled in here yesterday afternoon looking for dinner and some good basic Italian food.  WOW!  They knocked our socks off!

Speaking of knocking things off, our waiter looked like he could seriously be a mobster hit man.  But he provided delightful service and luckily the only offer I couldn't refuse was to bring me more Chianti.

Dinner started with a cup of minestrone which was to die for!  Steve ordered the homemade ravioli and I ordered the homemade cannelloni.  OMG!  Both were so unbelievable that I could not stop raving.  I must have been crazy to eat the whole portion because I felt so full for hours --but I couldn't stop!  Plus I kept reaching over the table to sneak nibbles off Steve's dish.  WOW!

The goofy castle decor just adds to the charm of this place.  Be sure to checkout the antique mirror with a 1940's nude pinup etched into it near the bathrooms.  Absolute cheesecake!  I made Steve go back just to see it.  I assume that the older Italian woman who sat us was the owner.  She was adorable!  All of the other patrons were seniors, but that's to be expected at a 40-year-old restaurant at 5pm on a Sunday.  

My only complaint was that the butter was served too cold to spread on the bread.  However the bread was *very* good and the foil wrapped butter warms up in your hand quickly enough.

I was going to give them four stars but I couldn't figure out what would keep me from going 5 --except the butter.  The food, service, attitude, bill, and parking, all beat most the hipster restaurants downtown.   They have an impressive wine list and I can't wait to come back and explore the menu and the wines, further.  

Dinner for 2 adults and 1 child, including appetizers and 3 glasses of wine: $70.
author: Amy A.

description:
Food is pretty bad here!  The place is in need of some serious remodelng unless you like places that take you back to the 70's 
Good place to film an old school mob flix too.  Bad lighting, bad makeup and bad food!!!
author: Seasbass A.

description:
If you read my reviews, you know I'm generous w/stars and rarely write a negative review. We'd heard about Gold Mirror the entire four decades of living in the Bay Area and finally a Saturday evening arrived when we had no other plans, were passing through the Parkside area, and were hungry for Italian food. I called -- no prob with table for 2 in 45 min. @7:00 p.m. (Gold Mirror is not on opentable.com/) Yes, it was crowded. It was also very noisy, which we kind of expected. 

7:09 p.m.: Husband: "I'd like the prawns dore. But can you substitute something for the rice?" Server: "How about mashed potatoes?" Husband: "That would be great. I'll have that instead of the rice."  (We wanted the sand dabs, but were surprised that so early in the evening, that menu special was unavailable.)

7:55 p.m.: Me: "We've been waiting for a long time for our dinner. Do you have any idea when it will be ready?" Server: "I'll check". (this, after he made sure ALL of the tables around us had their bottles of wine, drinks, and multiple plates of food; we had not ordered appetizers or drinks)

8:05 p.m.: Food arrives. My eggplant parmigiana is a small piece on a plate, all alone. While I didn't expect a bowl of vegetables or anything on the side really, I did expect a serving appropriate to the size of plate. It was plunked down on the table in front of me, server not wearing a mitt, so right away I knew it wasn't very  hot. I was so hungry, I just sucked it up & dug in. Server: "Sir, we'll bring your mashed potatoes separately." Husband: "Thanks."

8:15 p.m.: Husband (eating his prawns and vegetables, noticing there is also rice on his plate): "I did not get the mashed potatoes." Server: "I'll check." (remember: mashed potatoes were the SERVER'S idea, as opposed to baked potatoes or any other rice substitute).

8:20 p.m.: Server: "I'm sorry sir, the kitchen didn't have time to make mashed potatoes. We have people on vacation (blah, blah)". Husband: "Well, if I'd have known I couldn't have the mashed potatoes, I wouldn't have ordered the dore." He'd already started eating his dinner (of course, by then), so what to do?

I'm sorry to say (and I've never before done this), we finished, then left quickly, leaving no tip. Really, really wanted to like this place, but what kind of service is this? No mashed potatoes is not a sin in the restaurant biz, but not communicating w/customers on a timely basis is close to it. We did notice that tables with large parties got excellent service, local people were chummy with the servers, etc., and that the alcohol flows freely. Not fitting into any of these categories, we just kind of lost out. Flavors were good. Kitchen and restrooms are clean. Street parking is convenient. But we will not be returning. (Note to mystery fans: This is the restaurant on Taraval often mentioned in Marcia Muller's Sharon McCone novels.)
author: joyce h.

description:
I was really hoping to enjoy this place but didn't.  I bought a coupon from Restaurants.com and came to realize that the reason they are giving out the coupon is because the business is suffering.  We ordered:

Escargot- Best part of the meal, although a little over buttered and too much garlic.  

Tortillini - Horrible. Bland, Flavorless.  The cheese tasted EXACTLY like the powdered cheese in the $1.00 box of mac-n-cheese

Calamari Steak-  Not good.  Soggy and Spongy.  I'm pretty sure the rice was rice-a-roni too.  

Bread in basket- Very good, nice crunch, sour

Even at a discount, I would not return.   Chef Ramsey needs to get there stat and do a Kitchen Nightmare show.  

I really hate to bash a local business but this could have been the worst Italian food I have ever had.  Sorry, but these guys need a total food revamp..
author: Erica P.

description:
Been going to this place for years with my family.  The food is okay, but nothing great.  Service is also just ok.  Not too price. Here is what we had this time:

Canneloni - stuffed with veal, ricotta cheese, parmigiano reggiano, baked in a red and white sauce was delicious  
 
Veal Parmigiana - Average at best.  Some canned beans went with it.

Eggplant Parmigiana - Too sweet for me, but my mom did like it.  Comes by itself and looked strange without a side dish.

Petrale Sole Broiled with garlic and lemon was pretty good.  Came with a baked potatoe.

Spumoni and vanila ice cream was good.  Coffee was great.  We brought our own wine and paid the $15 per bottle corkage fee.

Would I come back again?  Yes, but not in a big hurry.
author: Michael M.

description:
My experience was awful.

I came here with my boyfriend hoping to get a nice Italian dinner. The hostess told us it'd be a 20-minute wait, which we were fine with. Only, she never followed up with us to see if we were staying, and walked off to every other part of the restaurant, COMPLETELY ignoring us, maybe even glancing our way with a, "they're still here?" kind of look.

You'd think it was just because it was busy, which I thought as well for a while. Until another two people walked in and were told it'd be a 20-minute wait, and she took down their name, the works.

We were feeling Italian but we went down the street to Sushi Zen and got treated a hell of a lot better even though they were busy as well.

Never coming here again.
author: Rusty S.

description:
This restaurant has never failed to satisfy my taste for Italian food ! I've been coming here for almost 25 years! 
I was so sad when their front door got smashed a few years back by the Safeway truck, I thought it was going to close for sure, but to my surprise, they opened and renovated the place!  My favorite is the Beef brochette, my son's favorite is their minestrone soup. Their spaghetti is cooked just right! I love their waiters, make you feel like you are having dinner in a 70's Pacino movie.
author: SJ L.

description: The food was Bad. The tortellini was bland. The baked oysters weren't on the shells; they seemed to be out of a can. The service was terrible. He also was quick to try to get us out of the door after we asked for the bill. Reviewing the bill, the final amount should've been $45. However, the server's math had the total as $78.00. When we called him over and told him about the bill not adding up, he was rude about trying to fix his mistake. We left a 15% tip, should've left a penny.
author: S D.

description: Inside is kind of gaudy, but the lasagna was really good. Service was decent and friendly.
author: Michael S.

description: My husband and I had a nice experience here overall. The ambiance is classy yet unassuming and totally cozy. Not sure when it was remodeled last but it did not appear run down. Our meal was delicious and the service was fantastic and flexible with our requests. I'd like to come back some time and try their classic full bar!
author: Anne Y.

description:
A rare "nice" restaurant in Parkside.  Most of the restaurants in the Parkside are casual, family-style type...this one actually has table cloths, an extensive wine list, chandeliers, and waiters who dress in tuxedos.  Very old school Italian, but food is OK good.

We shared the pan-fried calamari, which is listed on the menu as California calamari.  One word: Delicious!  It is pan-fried with garlic and green onions.  It is one of most tasty calamari dishes I ever had.  They don't give you "dips" to mask the taste like some places do.  It comes as is - delicious!!  A must have!

For entree, I ordered a pasta dish - spaghetti with fresh manila clams bordalese, fresh tomatoes and basil.  This was pretty good. Not great, but pretty good.  My husband ordered the Homemade Cannelloni, which is stuffed with veal, ricotta cheese, baked in a red and white sauce.  This I did not like.  I'm not sure if it's because of cheese or if the veal turned out to be a little tough.  

We ordered the Italian cream cake for dessert.  It is a chocolate sponge cake, layered with raspberry filling and mousse.  The cake tasted a little flaky and didn't have a great texture, but the combo of ingredients was good.

The prices are not cheap.  This is a classier place.   Appetizers go for about $10.  Pasta dishes about $15 and meat/seafood dishes go about $25.   Desserts are around $5.
author: Jannie Q.

description: The food here is surprisingly decent. I had the ravioli and it was pretty good although a bit too small especially for the price of $17. The biggest downfall of this place is the ridiculously slow service. I was there for nearly 90 minutes with only about 30 minutes of regular restaurant stuff (getting seated, ordering, eating, and paying).
author: Jon C.

description: Went to this place for my dads birthday. Its pretty good, I liked it. I had the capresse salad and the rosemary chicken. Lets start with the food, the food was good. It was very traditional Italian meal. The place is family owned, so I didn't doubt that they were more old school. The capresse salad I had, was with fresh tomatoes they were very crisp and juicy. The mozzarella was definitely freshly made. The entree of my meal was the rosemary chicken. The most juiciest and tastiest chicken ever. One of the best ones I have had. There was a abundant amount of sauce in every bite and the chicken fell off the bone into my mouth. The only thing I did not like was the fact that in the menu it said that the chicken came with rice and vegetables, however I did not receive the rice and had a small plate of vegetables which was on the side. I also had some Italian cake which was very fluffy and light after a good meal. It really tied the meal together. Now lets get to the service, the service was good and polite but very slow. Getting the waiters attention was difficult if we needed something and we waited a while to get the bill. In all the place is nice with good service, however they do need to fix the misunderstanding on the menus and say that the entree comes with a side of vegetables and no rice.
author: Svetlana T.

description:
I grew up just up the street. My family would always go here for birthdays since it was so conveniently close. It's a really nice Italian restaurant. Excellent food and a very friendly staff. Of all the years coming to the Gold Mirror, I've never had a bad meal. 

My brother and his family now live up the block and my parents and I still meet at the Gold Mirror to celebrate birthdays. We start off with the Gold Mirror Antipasto. I usually order the Veal Piccata. My family will order the Local Petrale Meuniere or the Calamari Steak. They are accommodating to my picky young nieces who only want buttered noodles. Great deserts - I love the Tiramisu and Italian Cream Cake. The family has never complained about the food either.  

Yes, this is old school Italian with waiters wearing tuxedos. Where do you get that these days? Classy is the word that comes to mind. This is not the Olive Garden or Buca Di Beppo. I would say this place is somewhere between casual & dressy but not formal. Please do not come if you are wearing sandals and shorts. I've never seen the place empty. There are always local neighborhood old couples and families. 

BTW, they can accommodate big groups. There is extra party room upstairs. They open it up on really busy nights. I've eaten up there before. There is also a full bar to the right as you walk in. The bar has cheese and Ritz crackers to eat while you wait for your dinner guests to arrive.
author: JohnnyAbsinthe J.

description:
Holy Canoli!!!   This place is a solid 5 STARS!!!

This is definitely a "family" place (both in the sense you generally find yourself coming here with your parents and aunts and uncles)  AND a family place as in you might actualy  run into a member of one of the "5 families" while you're eating in this place!!  

Here's whats great about it:  

The decor hasn't changed much (or at all) in the 50 years it's been here! AND true to it's name, there is a rather provocative large mirror with a scantily clad lady (ya gotta see this to believe it)  They did retrofit the front of the place after some drunk-O crashed into it a few years ago, but the decor? Naaahhh!

The waistaff is incredible!!!  Friendly, knowledgable, they'll treat you like family even after only going there once or twice...which of course makes you want to go even more...Their that awesome!

THE FOOD!! OMG OMG!!  Here are my favorites:

- Veal Picatta (tender, lemony, divine)
-  Stuffed shrimp
-  Clam linguine
-  Ravoilis
-  Caesar salad (wth anchovies baby and dee-lish garlicy croutons)
- Parmigiana (Egglplant, Chicken or veal..I've had them all and they are out of this world!!!)

Bread basket is even GREAT!!!

This past weekend I had a Caeser salad, the Veal Parm and am still having '"warm feelings" about it...

This place does seem to cater to an older set ...if you don't mind, go anytime.  However, if you go 8, 9ish, the crowd is much more mixed in age ranges...

Love that this place has a very good, well priced wine list (good job, sommelier)  and a full bar!! sometimes a gal just have to have a Martini or Manhattan while she peruses the menu

Desserts are great though frankly, I was so gorged on the bread and salad and meal I couldn't manage even a bite!  But they have the usual Italian restaurant offerings...cheesecake, tiramisu, canolis. 

The one thing I would change if I could is the parking! it's street parking and it's hit or miss, you'll either zoom right up or circle for 20 minutes!!!  Also, if you go during the day, the meters are only for an hour so bring some quarters with you!    It is right on the L Taraval Line...and 1 block from 19th Ave, you could catch the 28.   And there are some choice Irish pubs 2 blocks away so you could make an evening out of it!! 

Mangia Mangia!
author: Karen S.

description:
I've only been here once and all I can say is: Delicious. I was here months ago and I forgot to review about it but what I had was pasta with some sort of cream, truffles, chicken, and mushroom. It was amazing, probably one of my favorite pastas I've had ever since.

The ambience is really nice and classy, lots of things from the past but I wasn't here for the actual gold mirrors that were still up. Looking at the wall makes me think of the past... don't know why but it really does.

I would come back here anytime with a group for dinner, great place.
author: Bryan S.

description: Fantastic wine list , home made pasta , authentic cuisine. It's an OG place for sure!
author: Mel F.

description:
NO, not a fan.  Sorry if that's harsh.

Came here with the bf on a whim, what a bad decision.  Food was unremarkable.  Prices were absurd.  Portions were meager.  Decor was an atrocity. 

I will never return.  The only reason they don't get one star is because we didn't have to wait to be seated.  But maybe if we had, given the time, we would have come to our senses.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
I had passed by this place a million times and never knew there was great Italian food in the Sunset. 

     We walked in and were immediately transported to a setting in Italy, buon fresco walls, high ceilings, white table linens, arches, gates, and displays of abundant wine. We were welcomed and immediately seated by friendly staff.

      We ordered the fried calamari and it was about one of the best I've had. Lots of garlic, a smidgen of pepper, but not to much that it was spicy, and perfectly crisp. I had the meat ravioli with a tomato mushroom sauce and a glass of Super Tuscan to compliment. The pasta was fresh and simply delicious, however, my Mom had the special which was the fettucini with grilled chicken and wild mushrooms.  I was jealous because not only did I smell the truffle oil that was drizzled all over and saturated her dish, but it was far more superior in taste. Her dish was sooooooooooooooo good !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
   
     So if you're in the area, and you are tired of fighting for a parking spot in North Beach and having just okay Italian food, then pay a visit to the Gold Mirror Restaurant. You'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: Granolia G.

description:
We hadn't eaten at the Gold Mirror for at least 10 years, and since we we in the area we decided have dinner there.

Very disappointed.  We both remembered the food as being much much better. My escargot appetizer, served out of their shells in a heavy sauce, was not that tasty.  I don't know what was in the green sauce, probably pesto, but it had an odd, unsatisfying taste, which overpowered the escargot.  I prefer them in their shells with garlic and butter.  I didn't think to ask before I ordered, wrongly was assuming that it would be prepared that way.

My entree, Prawns Dore, were pretty good, lots of seasoning, but too much butter or whatever sauce, made them taste oily and took away from their flavor.  My husband had prosciutto raviolis in a white sauce.  Basically, no flavor and doughy.  

I don't even remember what I had for dessert - it was that unmemorable.

The check with one coffee and one glass of wine and tip, came to over $100.00.  Had it been a good meal, it would have been worth the price.

Will not be going back or recommending it to friends ... NO, not worth the price and the food was not that good.   The service however, was good and our water glasses were constantly filled.

We were seated not far from the front door even other tables were available. The door was constantly being opened by arriving and departing diners and it was a very cold night ... BURRRR.  I almost froze to death during my meal.
author: Canthespam P.

description: This is LITTLE ITALY in San Francisco! Started with a Cosmopolitan and it was the perfect Cosmo. Only other place that makes them the right color is Carmine's in NYC.  Thanks Bartender! Just wanted a home cooked meal so ordered a Mixed Green Salad tossed in a Vinaigrette and the Homemade Tortellini.  The salad was just as I remembered back at family style dinners on Wanda Street and the Cream Sauce on the Tortellini was so light that I didn't even feel guilty about the calories - so good!!!  Even the Chianti was good! Everything was so delicioso I ordered the Italian Rum Cake. OMG, it brought me back to the big Italian Weddings at Sons of Italy.  The topper was to see the DiGrande Brothers in the Kitchen. Itialians in the kitchen cooking Italian food - priceless.
author: FogCity D.

description:
We came here a few weeks for a family birthday dinner for my elderly parents, who are always looking for an Italian restaurant similar to their NY favorite, Stella's in Floral Park.  I remembered eating here several years ago, and figured it would be a good choice.

We received a nice greeting from a heavily Italian accented lady at the front door, and they were prepared to accommodate my dad in his wheel chair (I had given them a heads up).  Our ten guests trickled in and after we all settled in and had some cocktails and enjoyed the complimentary bruschetta, we began to order.  

Among the ten of us we managed to try quite a few items on the menu - the wonderful Caesar salad, a couple of the nightly specials - halibut in a piccata sauce (me) and the GIANT pork chop (Anton).  We also had the scampi, eggplant Parmesan, ravioli, salmon and some other entrees I can't recall.   The non-pasta entrees had sauteed chard as a side; nice and garlicky.  

We ended up the evening by ordering a selection of desserts - tiny cannoli, tiramisu and some other treats.  And of course Dad and Annabelle got their special desserts, complete with candle on top.

The only beef I have with GM is that the service is really really really slow, mainly because they only have a couple of waiters, and no food runners.  Meaning, that your waiter is the guy who brings our every single plate to your table with no assistance.  

That's just silly, considering that they had plenty of bussers who kept the tables clean.  I also think the fact that there was another large group (see David W's review - he was at the restaurant the same time we were) also caused the slowness.

In any event, a solid three stars and I'd definitely hit it again.
author: .Hon H.

description: The service was very poor.  The place was very busy but the waiters seemed clueless.   That would be fine I suppose if the food was good.  Very bland and unexciting.  Small portions for what you pay as well.  Typically I love an old school Italian restaurant but here the decor is sad and dated.  No mirrors in the place.
author: Liz R.

description:
This place is a good place to sit and talk. The food is bland. The place is kinda pricy too.

I like olive garden more than this place.
author: Taye N.

description:
Came here the other night fir dinner to celebrate my brother's birthday.  Surprisingly busy for an independent restaurant. 

Upon arrival, we were greeted and seated right away.  This restaurant is totally an old school Italian restaurant which I like.   I love it when restaurants like this keep it up but yet still look old school.  What I also admire is how the waiters wear their tux, kind of like Joe's of Westlake does, pretty cool!!!

Service was great :-). We ordered escargots and calamari for appetizers...it was awesome.  I'm pretty picky when it comes to bread and let me just tell you that their bread was YUMMY and warm.  The bread went well with the sauce that was with the escargots.  

We were all happy with our entrees.  My brother had the rib eye steak, which looked amazing.  It was served with mushrooms with a baked potato.  My brother's girlfriend had the halibut, which was served with swiss chard and a baked potato.  The halibut wasn't that fresh.  My mom had the eggplant parmigiana, which was great.  My daughter had the rigatoni with meatballs and bolengse sauce, it was delicious.  My dad had the lasgana...great taste.  I had the fettuccine with scallops.  One word for you for the fettuccine and scallops....WOW!!!

The only reason why I'm giving them four stars, I had ordered a garden salad and they forgot about it and cause the fish wasn't all the fresh.  Other than I was pretty happy with everything else.
author: Shana W.

description: God, this place is terrible.  My parents have always liked it, so I grew up eating here on occasion.  I never liked my food and would never choose to come here on my own.  Everything tastes like it came from an Italian TV dinner.  I'm shocked people are giving it 4 and 5-star reviews.  This is the kind of place that old people (like my parents) enjoy; the kind of food that was good in its time but hasn't kept up with today's standards of freshness and flavor.
author: Kandi K.

description: Went there for an adult family dinner...wonderful, old-school SF...we enjoyed a drink at the bar while we waited for the rest of our party and the bartender was friendly and attentive...our waiter was first rate...there was not a morsel left on anyone's plate. The starters and salads were beautiful and tasty...the main courses were delicious and the desserts were great. It was my first time at this gem, can't wait to go back!
author: Linda L.

description:
My friend, Jo, has been raving about this place forever so, today, I finally joined her there for lunch.  What a delightful time we had!  A bottle of excellent Italian barolo added to the festive atmosphere and we were delighted with our Italian waiter, Paolo, who was very attentive and charming.  The food was superb.  I had a tripe appetizer, in a tomato broth and garlic, beautifully seasoned, that was unbelievable.  Jo's gnocchi appetizer rivaled mine.  Our entrees were
both excellent - I had the eggplant parmagiana and she chose petrale sole.  For dessert, we ate the creme puffs.  The restaurant wasn't crowded on a Thursday afternoon though I hear weekend evenings, it's packed.  I think I'll stick with Thursdays afternoons and it's for sure I'll return!
author: Carmen H.

description:
My fiancee took me here last night for my birthday. We were a little skeptical, but it was so delicious. The service was great, the portions were reasonable (not giant bland salty dishes) and the food was great!! 

I had the scallops special and it was really fantastic. My fiancee's veal was also really tasty and his zucchini wasn't mushy and overdone. The minestrone was hearty and flavorful. We'll be going again!
author: Christine H.

description:
I was real disappointed after eating here.  

When you walk in, you get that nice, old school feel.  Like the mobsters used to eat here and plan their next crimes here. haha.

The service was horrible and took forever to do everything, order, receive, and get the check.

The food was extremely whatever.  It was bland and nothing i couldn't try to make myself at home.  It also came out separately.  Someone in my party had finished their dinner before i received it.

Food was overpriced.

Overall, I think Ernestos in the richmond is a much better choice, although you don't get the same atmosphere.
author: ryan l.

description: Poor service. Mediocre bland food. Outdated decor.  It seems like the people here are more interested in pleasing themselves instead of the customer.
author: T C.
