description: It was just ok...I got the Chicken Saute Sec, which would've have been much better with less sodium. The bf's Tortellini seemed a little dry to me, but he liked it. Olive Garden would've been a better choice for the money spent. I wouldn't come here again, but it wasn't horrible.
author: Ivy P.

description:
Like one Yelper said, this place is certainly very old school Italian.

They have some funky, castle-like decoration - which is both cute and comedic. There is a small table on a high balcony above the kitchen - overlooking everyone else. I came here two times, and I've never seen anyone sit up there. I wonder if patrons can dine there or if it's just for show. Either way, I want to sit up there there and play "queen" for a night.

Their wine list is not too shabby, I had a fabulous Pinot Grigio, Montevento (Della Venezie) that went well with my roast chicken.

Their roast chicken (two big pieces) is delicious. The skin was crisp and the meat fell off the bone - just the way I like it. Some veggies accompanied it. This dish is big - I could barely finish half. Their veal and ricotta Cannelloni was amazing. It was oozing out ricotta and the meat was cooked tenderly.

The desserts here are skippable. The coffee cake or some cake was heavily dunked in a sweet syrup..and it was way too sweet for my liking. Their tiramisu isn't too bad - but I've had better.

I would totally recommend this place. The food is delicious, the service is good and it's a great date place - probably with grandma or grandpa since the demographic seems to be mostly gray and white-haired couples, but then you know, this place is old school and real good. This restaurant is on Taraval Street - who knew great Italian food existed in the 'Set? Represent.
author: Vanessa W.

description: This review is based on a dinner on 12-18-13.  I have had dinner in The Gold Mirror on at least 4 occasions prior to this one.  Food:  Calamari Appetizer:  Greasy, tasteless and rubbery.  It included fish other than calamari.  Salad:  The equivalent of what you would get in an airline...in Coach.  Veal Piccata:  Tough, salty and in a brown sauce.  Veal Piccata should be in a white wine and caper/butter sauce.  This was indescribable.  Service:  The waiter was rude, inattentive and did not ask if we needed refills or assistance with anything.  Please keep in mind, this was a table of 5 native San Franciscans.  Prices:  Absurd for the mediocre and embarrassing food they provide.  In short, this is a restaurant that has lost its passion and desire to serve its patrons.  Avoid.
author: Mark H.

description:
What a cute old school restaurant! We stumbled onto this place purely by chance while trying to find any place that had parking within a decent distance. 
We shared a dinner salad with blue cheese dressing that was great. I appreciate that they separated it for us. One of the appetizer specials was gnocchi with Gorgonzola and mushroom sauce. There was no way we could pass that up. It did not disappoint. It tasted even better when followed with Peroni beer on tap.

I have been avoiding ordering lasagna for quite some time as I haven't found any restaurants that can provide what I'm looking for. I don't want a 10 layer, bland serving of noodles, sauce and hamburger but that's generally what I get. I went ahead and ordered it here and the waitress said it was a "good choice." Yeah, yeah, yeah, that's what they all say.  OMG! This is THE best lasagna I've had in years. It was slightly crunchy on the outside with just enough sauce and tons of cheese. My dining partner tried it and stated it was the best they've ever had. 

I love the charm of this place. It's obvious they have quite a few regulars and there were tables of families celebrating Mother's Day. Our waitress was great. I wish I would have caught her name. She said she usually works lunch. The other staff were all extremely attentive and friendly.
author: Christina H.

description:
Had dinner at the Gold Mirror last night and it was delicious! 

I live in the Sunset and come to the GM about 6 times a year and have to say that after last night, I was very impressed. I started with the Gnocchi special (in a white sauce with mushrooms and chicken). It was so flavorful and the gnocchi were like floating pillows - so light they melted in my mouth. LOVED it!! Then I had the fillet skewers with button mushrooms. Loved the detail on the mushrooms. Tasted my BF's prime rib (also a special), it was a generous portion and was very good. For dessert I had the Spumoni (my fave!) and tasted my BF's home made cheesecake with berry coulis. Appreciated that the cheesecake was individual, not just a cut piece of a cake. It was really good. 

I really enjoyed my meal, from start to finish. A lot of thought and detail went into each dish I tasted. The service was good and the bus girl was very attentive. She would make a great waitress. 

Can't wait to go back!!
author: EVELYNE E.

description:
So i live really close to this place and have walked by it a million times.  Seniors was getting old (drunken nights) so i decided to come here 

When i walked in the atmosphere was that of a locally established spot there were a few regulars at the bar and the inhabitants were mainly old people probably because people my age dont usually pay 15 bones an entree....but if you want good Italian food this place dose it right. I got the broiled salmon  &. minestrone date got the fettuccine nice place too expensive for me.
author: Matteo C.

description:
STIFF STIFF D---KS . . . guaranteed to make you feel gooooood.

get your dirty minds outta the gutter, the word is DRINKS. shame on all of you. the food is good but I mostly come to Gold Mirror for pretty ambiance and small parties. the upstairs room is great for an intimate gathering; more than 40 guests would be too tight, and there's no bar up there so you'd better tip nice when the waiters scurry to and fro w/ your libations. no one waited more than a couple of minutes, and the drunkier ones went downstairs themselves to avoid any wait at all. desperate drunkards. it's a new show on channel 7, check it out.

I had the prime rib which was nice and the boy had a really lovely veal parm. I love the decor ! this is a place to sit, relax, and enjoy your food and drink in charming surroundings.
author: Prima D.

description: I've been here 3 times with my partner, and each time the food and service have been wonderful.  Yeah, the decor could certainly use an upgrade, but that's part of the charm, and it certainly adds to the "old school" feeling and doesn't take away from the meal.  For the quality and quantity of food I believe it's well priced.  You can tell they put a lot of pride in their food and that they have a strong following of locals.  Many of the patrons are up there in age, so another plus of going here is feeling like a youngster at 40.  One of the few Italian resturants that actually sell Lemmoncello...Yum!!
author: Sean M.

description:
I really like the ravioli here-big platforms with spinach, cheese, a good hint of lime.
They have Peroni beer on tap. Full bar.
Bathroom is clean.
Old school to the max, with waiters wearing tuxes. 
On the bar they have cheese and Ritz crackers available.
Available for private events with an upstairs banquet area.
esSeff,Dig? This isn't your son's or daughter's restaurant.
Not inexpensive, but recommended.
author: Mag N.

description:
Waiter in tuxedo?  Check.
Same waiter with an Italian accent?  Double check!
Certifiably old-school Italian restaurant ina somewhat random location?  Check check check.

Seriously loved this place.  It could be the Italian blood flowing through my veins but I think a place like this has universal appeal.  Plus I could totally imagine my Italian grandmother coming here back when she lived in the city.  We started with some drinks at the bar (that had this cool red-lit ceiling thing going on) which were affordable and strong.  Whoo!  And I thought the food was reasonably priced and pretty darn good.  If you have a craving for old school Italian, there probably isn't anywhere better.
author: Leslie R.

description:
This place would have gotten 4 stars if it wasn't for our inept waiter.   We should have known better when he didn't write our order down.  

We ordered our salads and a cup of minestrone soup that my boyfriend said was good.  We ordered the escargot also to share, but when I saw the waiter coming to our table with our entrees, I knew he had forgotten our appetizer.  My boyfriend was livid!  Not only did the old waiter have an attitude to begin with, he had forgotten our appetizer and totally shrugged it off! 

 If my boyfriend's Mom and I hadn't calmed him down, this waiter would've been tossed out on the sidewalk...it's funny how one thing can totally drag a dinner down and it totally happened when this waiter forgot our appetizer!!!! Ugh! Annoying!!!  

Aside from that, my veal piccata was delicious although the portions weren't that big.  The old waiter tried to make amends by giving us a free dessert of cannoli and saying that the coffee was on him and that "our escargots are not that good anyways." 

Ooo-kay...don't let your manager hear you telling that to the customers!!!!  

My boyfriend has stated he is NEVER coming back here again...I'd have to agree and it was all because of the bad service!!!
author: Jade B.

description:
Been coming here for most of my life.  My parents took me here when I was a kid, and I was convinced that this place had the best minestrone and spaghetti w/meatballs in the world.  I still think the same way.

Of course, as I matured, I tried other dishes, like that steak medallions with red-wine, the veal marsala, the chicken, and all the other great dishes.  And now that I'm an adult, I've come to appreciate the beer and wine selection too.  Funny, but the spaghetti and the minestrone are still my two favorite!!

The cooking overall has always been top-notch, and thoroughly consistent.  The food is hearty but never heavy feeling.  
As a kid, I used to make sure I would be seated next to the window so I could see into the kitchen.  The comfort, the care, the love in that cooking!

Every time I come I KNOW what to expect, and it's worth the money because the service is excellent.  Every waiter we've had (many different ones have come and gone through the years) has been super prompt with water and checking our status on everything.  The place is clean, cozy, intimate, and has that familiar, nostalgic feel.

The only weird thing was this past time I visited for my birthday celebration and the waiter kept trying to up-sell us on everything, and it was a bit overbearing.  At the end, he gave us his business cards offering to sell us snowboards at wholesale pricing.  Someone should make sure that guy is kept in check.  Other than that, he was thoroughly hilarious and kept us happy the whole night.

I wouldn't call this place 100% Italian, because there are some obvious French influences as well (and especially escargot for you snail-eaters out there).

Random historical fact about Gold Mirror:

One time, a truck backed up into the entranceway and destroyed the place, but they took the opportunity to remodel.  They did a nice job, and kept a lot of the original vibe, although I do miss the abundance of warm yellows and reds the interior used to have.
author: Warren L.

description:
Ok, I was skeptical from reading some of the reviews.  I really love Italian food and love going to Parma in the Marina.  I like food with a lot of flavor.  I had passed this place on the muni so many times and had no idea what was inside (windows are tinted so you can see out but not in).  

Maitre De - big smile greeting us
Waiter - Attentive, nice, young, knew everything about the wines on the wine list and made sure we were happy
Ambiance - A really nice atmosphere, open, spacious, clean and relatively modern.  It's a place to bring your family, even the uppity ones who turn their nose up at most places.  It was filled with all races and ages and happy smiling people really enjoying their food.
Food:
- Freshly baked bread, came in hot.  Delicious!
- Red Pinot Noir  - 2 glasses (McMannis - YUM)
- Appetizer: Garlic Fried Prawns - So good!  I was dragging them in the garlic on the plate and savoring every bite.
-  Entrée 1 - Homemade Cannelloni stuffed with veal, ricotta cheese, parmigiano reggiano, baked in a red and white sauce (something I never do, but it is one of their house specials)  It was soooooo good.  I loved it,  Very rich & done to perfection, add some black pepper and a little red pepper and zing!  
- Entrée 2 - My husband ordered the special which had fresh pasta, Chicken and mushrooms in a really nice cream sauce.  He loved it and told me multiple times how good it was (which is rare...it's usually.  Yep pretty good).

We both cleaned our plates and vowed to return.  The desserts we saw looked amazing, but we were stuffed and sooo happy.  My expectations were low and they far surpassed them.  I think I prefer this to Parma now!  I'm excited to go back and try their other dishes!
author: Wendy C.

description:
So my friends and I stumbled upon this old-fashioned Italian place the other day in search of pasta. When we walked in, we were greeted very kindly. Just like the review noted below me, our waiter did look like he was in a mafia. He was super nice though. 

We looked at our menus, and since none of us knew much Italian, we were kind of like "So...what's _____ ?" We asked our waiter what a majority of the words were, and it seemed like he was thinking "What in the world are these kids doing in here?" So enough with the story.

 I eventually ordered the homemade ravioli, and my goodness, these ravioli squares were probably the biggest ravioli squares I've eaten. They were stuffed with veal, chicken, and some other things topped with a seasoned tomato sauce. It was yum.

The service was really good. They always refilled our c ups of water, even before we were halfway done. We finished our bread appetizers and he asked us if we wanted more. What I love most about the service was when after we said we didn't want anymore, he came back a while more and asked if we were sure we didn't want any more bread. I call that service.

When we got the bill, it was handwritten with like squiggles for writing. It seemed like they overcharged us, but we couldn't really tell since we could barely read it. 

Other than that, good Italian food with just as good service.
author: Tee C.

description: I've been passing the by the Gold Mirror for 3 years since I moved from the Noe Valley to Parkside. Last night I was feeling italian food, my husband says "how bout the Gold Mirror?" We took a chance. Our waiter Dominco I believe that was his name heavy italian accent which made the experience all the more better. White napkins, fresh warm bread, all male wait staff which I love! We had Manhattans to start they were awesome, and calamari. Now he informed us that they only had half an order left but they could fill in the other half with prawns, prawns were chunky and full of flavor. Lightly  breaded and lightly fried. Superb flavor. I had Veal Scalopini hubby had Veal Cannelloni. Our waiter paired our dishes with the according wines. After dinner he came with the desert and port & grappa menu. I had Tiramisu hubby had the cheesecake and two espresso macchiato! I also loved the fact that the manager was there hosting, checking on food, checking in with customers and was really involved. Very old school but that's the way it should be old school with a lot of class !
author: Roxanne O.

description:
The restaurant that saved Christmas.

I've lived in the Parkside for 20 years, I've shopped at the Safeway forever, now I literally live around the corner from The Gold Mirror.   I don't go out to eat much, particularly in the Taraval corridor.  Let's face it, there's not too much here that really tops what I can cook myself and I'm not a huge fan of Chinese food (I appreciate the irony). How satisfying is it to be able to find a really good restaurant that you can walk to in five minutes?

The test of a restaurant is how it is under pressure.  How about Christmas night for pressure?  How about your parents visiting?  How about I've never been here before?
They came through with flying colors.

A 10 minute wait while the first seating cleared out, a table by the window and simply excellent food.  I love restaurants without pretense, that have been what they are and refuse to make you think they're anything else.  This is that place.

A lovely wine list, really good bread. Something about the crackly crust...

A tossed green salad or lentil soup.  Loved the little shrimps on the tossed green salad (I'm a sucker for little shrimps) and their vinaigrette is really nice. Okay, I'll admit it, I dunked the bread in the salad dressing. Sue me.

We love veal. They serve veal. They rock the veal.  Scallopini was fork tender (Mom's choice).  The sweetbreads, well, a month later and my Dad's still talking about them.  Veal Saltinbocca (my choice) rich, luscious, brilliant (the prosciutto makes it salty, if you're sensitive to such things). Their sauces are uniformly excellent.  I could actually taste the marsala and the brandy in the sauce. They don't over complicate things and I appreciate dishes that are simple, classic with attention to detail.   For me, the vegetable choice can be a real buzz-kill.  I love green beans, something I hardly ever see at restaurants.   Guess the veg: Green beans.  And perfectly cooked.

The service was really quite good, considering the place was packed. A little wait for more bread, but not that big a deal. 

Another test of a restaurant is how much you look around at what other people have ordered and take mental notes for next time.  We did that a lot. The stuffed shrimp looked ridiculously good. It puzzles me is that they don't have their menu out front, which they should.

Why did it take me so long to stop in?  Lesson: Don't judge a restaurant by its neighbors.

I wouldn't normally review a restaurant, because it is such a personal experience.  Everyone's got their own expectations and sometimes you just  go on an off night.  But the Gold Mirror deserved my registering on Yelp because they were there when I needed a great dinner on Christmas in my neighborhood. And I will be back for the Stuffed Shrimp.  And the Salmon. Ooo and the Filet.  Those ravioli look aaamazing!
author: Der G.

description:
I agree with Steve G. -- "utterly sublime cannelloni." I've been on a "Search for the Ultimate Cannelloni" quest for a long time, and Gold Mirror's ranks among the best.
Extra good news: many places that serve cannelloni in the Bay Area only offer it on the dinner menu. Here's you can get it for lunch.
As a Belgian beer fan, I was delighted to see that they had a Belgian style black beer (brewed by the 1554 brewery) on draft -- excellent.
Oh yes -- our server, Linda, was extremely nice and helpful, and added a good-times flair to the establishment.
Gold Mirror: Highly recommended!

LATER:
Been back several times , and the cannelloni is STILL outstanding!
author: Arthur C.

description: Simply said... This is my new favorite Italian Restaurant in San Fran!! If you haven't tried the Calamari, its AMAZING!!!
author: William S.

description:
I've passed by this restaurant for the past several months and didn't think it appeared to be anything special. After looking it up on Yelp and seeing the great reviews, my boyfriend and I decided to go there to celebrate our anniversary.

I was surprised to discover a restaurant with great food, drinks, service and ambiance. My boyfriend had the broiled salmon (cooked perfectly!) and I had the seafood pasta in an olive oil and garlic sauce. I am in love with the sauce on my pasta!! My Grey Goose dirty martini was perfectly done as well. I thought my dessert was a bit blah, but I'm fairly certain that was just my own tastes and not a reflection of the restaurant. My boyfriend loved his homemade cheesecake which was softer than your average cheesecake and just wonderful.

We'll be back, that's for sure.
author: Tara D.

description:
One word describes this place for me: meh. Came here for lunch and expecting good things especially for the price we paid. The roast chicken was a sad disappointment. The sauce was too bitter. The spinach and rice were acceptable. However, I am not giving this as few stars as I would've if the fish of the day was not made so well. 

Service here was extremely slow. There were only two other tables being occupied when we got here. It does not take 45 minutes to cook two entrees. Prices are a bit ridiculous even for lunch hour. I don't plan on coming back anytime soon.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
If old school Italian with a real neighborhood feel is what you are looking for, this place could fit the bill.  I was there on a Wednesday night and it ended up packed with all sorts of locals from the surrounding areas.  The parking - as with any neighborhood joint - sucks.

The food is very good.  The cannelloni is a must try.  It's lightly sauced, and stuffed with veal and ricotta. The best I've tasted in a long time.  The Eggplant Parmesan was a bit over the top with sauce and cheese for me, but it was good.  The bread is warm and crusty.  I'll likely to return and try some of the other dishes.

You won't find any molecular gastronomy or the trend of the day here.  Just solid food and solid service.  A great spot for  a relaxing evening.  Go see Sam and Paulo and the crowd.  You will enjoy yourself.
author: Randy C.

description:
The BEST Homemade Fettuccine Alfredo I've ever had! Melt in your mouth goodness that will have you begging for more, despite the fact that you're soooo full and didn't realize you've cleaned the painted flowers off the plate. 

Once you've become regulars, you're treated like family. The service is great, and the owners, Giuseppe Di Grande and family, are friendly and accommodating. Thanks, my friend.

Oh, and I can't forget to mention the hotness that emanates from the kitchen. And I don't mean the crushed red peppers. Every time I go I have to situate myself to face the window that looks into the kitchen because I love seeing the two FINE chefs, Domenico and Roberto, makin' my yummy food! Gives a nice twist to the saying "The way to a woman's heart is through her stomach"  with a glass of Merlot and a plate of their Fettuccine Alfredo. Mmm! Mmm! Good!
author: Kathryn F.

description: This is another great Italian place that my friends and I love. The bartender Karen kicks ass!!!!! The garlic oysters are to die for and it feels like you're feasting in a castle. Oh and the chef is super cute and will make you the best chicken parmasean ever!
author: sabrina o.

description:
Best part about my first trip to the Gold Mirror was a parting comment from a patron at the next table who recommended the pan-fried calamari.

"It's like Sophia Loren without a bra."

I can't attest to that fact, but I can tell that I will have to go back and investigate.
author: Kennelco C.

description:
We just tried Golden for the first time.  It was a great experience.  After reading the other reviews I was hopeful we wouldn't get that rogue waiter and we didn't.  Ours didn't spend an excessive amount of time with us but he was pleasant and helpful.
I had the calamari, lightly breaded with an herb crust and served in a light olive oil base.  I've never had calamari like this and it was great.  Next came the Caesar salad, anchovy and all.  the Caesar dressing was a little different than I'm used to with a sort of balsamic base but again was wonderful.  Next came the final course, Veal Malinese.  All I can say is I would order this dish over and over again.
If you like Italian food and want a good meal for the price, Golden Mirror is the place for you.   It's definitely worth a visit.
author: Buster K.

description:
Speaking of old fashioned Italian food.  This would be the place.

I always see this place on my way to my co-workers for carpooling like everyday, and we never knew what kind of place it was or could we see inside because of the fact that the windows were always covered up.

So one day we decided on to go, just for the hell of it.  The food was good for the price, nothing too fancy, but nothing bad to say about it either.  Portions were generous.  But it seemed like the place your grandmother would take you to.  Like it puts the OLD in old fashion.  We were like the only people under 50 in there that night. HA!
author: Clifford C.

description:
Nice Italian American food in a quirky, trying-to-be-elegant-but-not-quite-making-it atmosphere

The Gold Mirror serves old school cuisine... pastas, steaks, fish, and so on.  There aren't any surprises on the menu, but the old favorites don't disappoint.  The wine list offers a good selection across a wide set of price points.

Service is excellent -- attentive but unobtrusive.  

The room is high-ceilinged (there's a private mezzanine overlooking the dining room that's used for parties), but the noise level isn't bad at all.  Background music skews towards Sinatra and the standards. The decor is unintentionally humorous.

It can be breezy and cool if you're seated by the door, so ask for an inside table.  Waiting at the bar is no hardship... cocktails are deftly prepared and served.

On our most recent visit we had cocktails, apps, entrees (one pasta, one steak) and a bottle of red and got out the door for $125 including (generous) tip.  It's a comfortable place with very good food and stellar service.
author: Judi A.

description: I ate here every week when I lived in San Francisco... I love their Hearts of Palm salad, sweetbreads, steaks and VEAL to die for....  get there early, have a drink at the bar and enjoy a bit of Old San Francisco.....
author: T L.

description: Came here with boyfrend and family for dinner one night because of a restaurant.com voucher I wanted to use. Service and food is good but waaaay overpriced! They also didn't accept my $50 restaurant.com voucher even though there's no expiration date!
author: Jess H.

description:
Well, I typically give good reviews, but this restaurant left us unsatisfied at best. We had a decent sized party and none of us were very happy...to say the least.

Ambience - It was your run of the mill restaurant inside. Clean, but boring. Where was the Gold Mirror!? All kidding aside, this doesn't account for too much of my rating anyways...so let's get to the food and service.

Food - The Minestrone soup was actually served cold (not on purpose) to me. When they heated it up, there was not very much flavor, and I had to add a bit of salt. (I never add salt) The Calimari was average...and some pieces tasted burnt. At least they gave tentacles, which a lot of other restaurants neglect to serve. I had the Tortellini with Prosciutto and cream sauce. The Prosciutto was not so abundant and the cream sauce tasted like Costco brand sauce. Yuck. The portions were average size, but when done right, portions don't have to be large. Others in the party had Saltimboca and other Veal dishes. They claimed the dishes to be very bland. None of us had dessert since we had a nice cake to cut at home. Thank goodness.

Service - The servers were friendly, and attentive. The problem was that our main server seemed inexperienced with his delivery. Again, not that important. The busser had amazingly strong B.O. which bothered some people in the party, but I didn't pay attention.

Bar - Looked like a nice bar to have a few drinks before you start your night out, but didn't get a chance to enjoy it that night.

Overall - This was the last place I would go to have Italian food. We are blessed with so many great Italian restaurants in the North Beach area, and even 2 much better Italian offerings only 5 blocks away in West Portal, I can't see how the Gold Mirror has stayed in business since 1949.
author: Michael M.

description: Gold Mirror Italian Restaurant: overpriced and horrible food, beside worst restaurant service experienced that I ever had.  Oh, yeah! This is the highlight of the evening: in their menu the Escargot is $8.00 but in our bill the Escargot was charged for $12.00.  Are you kidding me? When we politely addressed this matter to the server and he did NOT once apologized to us.  For this reason, we only tipped him last than 15%.  Bottom line: first time shame on you (Gold Mirror Italian Restaurant) and for sure NEVER in this lifetime will I return to you because the food, prices, and services at Olive Garden is much better than Gold Mirror.
author: Lorna t.

description: Looks can be very very deceiving...when you walk into this restaurant you think what is this place, but the food is to die for...the butter and garlic prawns as well as the stuffed prawns are favoloso!!!!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
There are plenty of reviews here, so I'll keep it simple: Best. Eggplant Parmigiana. Ever.

I love this place, and have since I was a wee bairn.
author: Marissa K.

description: I have been going to the Gold Mirror for almost 30 years, as an adult. The food is good, yes, and a star for the server who was very professional and charming. However last night was my last visit to the gold Mirror, ever. My disenchantment started about 2 years ago when I used to go once or twice a week after class and have a couple glassed of wine and an appetizer at the bar. Being a bartender myself it is common curtesy to occasionally top off a patron's glass of wine with an ounce or two or more so, comp a drink. Well there was a stop put to that, and I could see that there was a watchful eye prohibiting the bartenders discretion for customer appreciation. So I had not been in for quite a while when my husband and I had a taste for reliably delicious Italian food, so I thought we'd give it another shot and sit in the dining room. It was 7:45pm and only one other table finishing up. Why did it take 20 min to get bread? Both server and bus lady checked and said it wasn't up yet. O.K., then we order, shrimp and  scallop fettuccine for me, $24.00, and chicken piccata for the husband. Thirty-five minutes later, we were surprised to receive such small portions, especially for a pasta dish priced at $24.00. Four bites and 5 min later our plates were clean and we were still hungry. Seriously: four fork bites of pasta, 3-4 tiny shrimp and two small scallops. Chicken dish had 8 green beans and about 3 tablespoons of rice. We shared an appetizer which was a half avocado with a spoonful of crab in it: $15.00. We had one glass of house wine each, and needless to say when the $81.00 bill came we were not only hungry, but exasperated. I left $100, and 15 minutes later we were at home making tuna sandwiches. That is just wrong. We all work hard for our money. Nickel and diming your customers for a couple ounces of wine OR pasta is not going to "make your numbers" it is going to break them. It is pasta for God's sake, a low cost item that a diner should always have a little left over to take home with them, I am surprised that as established as The Gold Mirror is, this isn't acknowledged. As well we all know in this business that when folks have a good experience they share it with 2 or 3 others, but when they have a bad one, they tell 10 people. I just want to warn my friends so they aren't out 100 bucks of their hard earned money for absolutely nothing.
author: punk l.

description:
This is super classic old Italian supper club style done well. In a sea of fusion and foam cuisine, sometimes the basics can actually feel novel - especially when set in a Venetian castle on Taraval.

Lee and I shared a caprese salad that could have used a bit more flavor - the tomatoes were kind of bland, then again, it is December - and the basil was a chiffonade, instead of bigger pieces which I prefer. The caprese did, however, come with what I can only describe as a Tower of Pisa roll of prosciutto, which lent a salty, savory element to the salad.

My calamari steak was tender, but lacked substantial flavor and Lee's fettuccine was perfectly al dente in a rich cream sauce with just the right touch of nutmeg.

The one major sore spot? The glasses of wine we ordered had not been decanted and we were left with sediment sludge at the bottom of our glassware.

The service, however, was on point and we ended with a lovely meal.
author: Joanna R.

description: I have gone to this restaurant for years with local SF family. Aside from the management changes over the 20 years, the food and service remained good enough to return - at time/periods - very very good. However, in the last couple years I am now done with the rude service across the board. It is remarkable as the food is often good. Sadly, after several visits over a year or more, we are calling it quits.
author: Bridget B.

description: great old world ambience. Staff were great, accommodating. Our party of 3 all loved their choices. A great place to go for a very home style meal. Our waiter was even Italian.
author: Matt T.

description:
I've always enjoyed dinner at the Gold Mirror, but my first lunch there recently was VERY DISAPPOINTING.  The main entree was fine, but the sides were barely lukewarm, and the clam chowder was "dishwater".  Most of all it was the waiter's attitude that would keep me from going back.  Why can't they find pleasant waiters???  This one paced back and forth waiting for one of my guests to finish her salad.  It was most annoying, and there were not many tables taken so what was the rush.  Furthermore, the pieces of romaine were so large she had to cut each and every one; I would have just given up.  I know the Gold Mirror can do better, but I won't  waste my time or money to give them another try.  Too bad!  It used to be a good place.

Peggy H.
author: Peggy H.

description: Love the Gold Mirror. A  little to dark on the inside, makes reading the menu tough. So, just listen to the waiter and say "I'll have the Prime Rib." Good cocktails and warm bread. Enough said.
author: dave d.

description:
We had a very pleasant experience here for our New Year's Dinner.  We had been wanting to come here ever since they remodeled it.  So it just happened we were in the neighborhood, we were getting hungry as dinnertime approached and my mom actually had their phone number in her purse so......

My Sis called in, asked if they had a table for 4 and voila......  
We were there, parked, within 2 minutes and in we go.....

Right off the bat, we were greeted by the friendly host and seated.  The decor was very nice in there.  They certainly did a good job with the remodel.  

The food was tasty.  The portions seemed a little small to us but it still filled us up so nothing to complain about.  We all agreed that the best thing we had was the Italian Cream Cake for dessert.  We would go back to the restaurant just for that.  Though the rest of the fare we had was pretty good too.  And our waitress, Linda was also extremely friendly.  A great start to the New Year!!!!
author: Mark W.

description:
3.5 stars really... everything was good but not spectacular. Having a place withing walking distance of my house where there's decent italian and waiters in tuxedos is pretty cool. 

I ordered the seafood pasta special, with white sauce. The waiter said that the pasta is homemade but I have serious doubts about it. It didn't have that "doughyness" that homemade pasta has. The seafood was 3 types of fish, salmon, sole and some other white fish I couldn't identify, clams and prawns. The fish was all a bit bland but the prawns and clams were good. The white sauce was really delicious though, with lots of garlic and just a bit of red pepper flakes.

The BF had the New York steak, which was odd because in the year and a half that we've been dating I've never seen him eat a steak. He asked for it medium well. It was juicy and flavorful. He said the potato tasted weird though. With him that could mean anything.

For dessert he had the tiramasu, and I had cream puffs. I also have a sneaking suspicion that the cream puffs are not home made, but they were tasty none the less. I liked the tiramasu much better.

Since it's 2 blocks away, I'm sure we'll be back. I'll have to try the lasagne next time
author: Melanie V.

description: we went on Sunday night,  reservations for 10 at 6pm.   We sat down at about 6:10pm,  ordered before 6:30pm.   Our dinner was not served until a little after 7:30pm.  Over an hour wait at the table for our food.  We also ordered several bottles of wine.  I believe when a restaurant has you wait over one hour for your food "after you have ordered" is unacceptable.   Our waiter did not even acknowledge the wait, or apologize.  We inquired  why it was taking so long.   The service was the worst.  I think that the least they could have done,  was to comp one bottle of wine for us,  that would have been a nice gesture.  How do you keep someone waiting for over an hour for their meal?  That is really bad!!!!   The food was okay.   With our dinner came about 3 spoonfuls of rice and 4 green beans.  For the price you pay,  I would expect a little more rice and veggies... just saying.... can't be that expensive for them to add more rice and veggies.  Why would an Italian restaurant serve a side of rice and vegetables instead of  a side of pasta?  That makes more sense.   When asked if we could have a side of pasta instead of rice,  they said it comes with rice.   I will not go back,   there are so many more restaurants that have better food and better service,  why go here???  Never again.....
author: Deborah M.

description:
My lovely neighbours, Dom and Berto hold it down like no other! I've had my 20th birthday, Valentines day, my girlfriends birthday, new job celebrations, and good ole munchies here at the GM! This is the dankest, italian cuisine in the city! They get all their Fish from local fishermen, veggies from the farmers market, and recipes from the family. You can't go wrong here. PLUS the bar is super sweet, the servcie is great, and Berto has been knwon to hook it up with a shot here and there...
HOLLAR!
author: Allen W.

description:
I've only gone here once with my boyfriend. The decor of the restaurant is nice so that's what that one star is for. Other than that, the chicken fetucci sucked! The chicken was gross, but the old italian waiters were nice.

Enough said. ;)
author: Jessica R.

description:
The staff is friendly and I expected so much out of this restaurant because I live down the block and can frequently smell the pleasing aroma wafting down the block. I walked in and was greeted warmly and seated. The place had a nice feel to it especially because I didn't expect it by looking at the outside of the restaurant. 

The food... was bad. I am really disappointed because it always smells so damn good! The food wasn't good tasting and it upset my stomach afterward. It's also disappointing because the prices are so high but the food quality isn't great. It's definitely a neighborhood spot and attracts loyal patrons who happen to be older and Caucasian. I would definitely avoid this place to save your money.
author: Christina B.

description:
The food is pretty good. Our only complaint was that they use a bit too much salt. 

The service is decent, and prices very reasonable. The decor is so ridiculous and over the top that it's actually entertaining.
author: Robert R.

description:
This is one of the most friendliest restaurant you can go to, however, the food besides one item was less than satisfactory. 
Perhaps it was what I ordered, the veal marsala where I though the rice was dry and the veal needed to be seasoned and cooked better. 
The one item that we collectively enjoyed was the fried calamari. I enjoyed the entire squid that is fried with the eggs with it, great breading. 

I felt that the desserts were not spectacular pertaining to size or quality. I think if you were to buy the cream puffs or tiramisu in the supermarket, you would find equal or better-tasting replicas.
author: Thia T.

description:
I remember this place before it was renovated, and i liked it a lot more back then. It has an old school decor about it, which is appealing to the eye. The people there are extremely nice, although it is slightly funny, because they try to seem like they are a very up-scaled place, and they don't realize they're in the taravel district. 

The food is alright. Again, they think their things are fancy when in fact the way they come out is just ok. I find its best to stick to the originals here, cause it wont come out too weird. It ok food, that's all.
author: Casey Z.

description:
My last 2 visits here were very good.
The garlic prawns as an appetizer are fabulous.

The best things I've had here have been the filet mignon and the roast chicken.  In fact, I'd definitely order any of the chicken dishes here again since that was probably the best entree I've had there.

I wasn't so pleased with the various fish entrees I've tried -- they're okay, but kind of plain and the presentation definitely needs work -- it's basically a piece of fish on a plate, not much else.

The zabligione dessert is a must-have -- they whip it up while you wait and serve it warm in a glass which has a light coating of sweet red wine. along with a cookie.  It is incredible -- very rich and fluffy.
author: D Z.

description: What are you folks raving about? The food was mediocre at best, I couldn't really taste it. The service was awful...I couldn't find our waiter most of the time, we constantly needed water. The bread was sad. I was disappointed all around. It was loud too, our family had to yell at one another to be heard. Very very cramped, tables waaaay too close! Boring menu, boring food, bad service. Not ever going back. Tacky decor. Not a winner.
author: Chrissy D.

description:
I am writing this on behalf of my parents. 

They had a horrible experience here at The Gold Mirror. 
They were ignored by the staff, no one came to take their drink order, and the waiter was rude and dismissive. He never made any suggestions or recommendations of what to order. 

On top of it all, they would not honor the restaurant.com Gift Certificate. When asked why- they provided no response. My parents up and left angry and disappointed. 

Never coming back and giving this place a second chance.
author: Frances J.

description: Hands down the best lasagna I've EVER had! I would like to say I'm a lasagna conosur and by far this is the best. I find myself day dreaming about it sometimes... The pasta is homemade and it's super thin which is a delightful twist on a traditional lasagna. Overall it's creamy, great tomato cheesey flavor, beefy goodness with a wonderful golden cheese top. I'm considering buying the pasta making gadget for my Kitchen Aid so I can recreate this at home in Chicago.
author: Monique O.

description: Old school, classic.  The lasagna is amazing.  I don't even like lasagna, and I love the lasagna here.  Chicken is also solid.  Look around -- many of the guests look like they are from New Jersey.  This is not an accident.  NJ has amazing Italian food, and these folks know where to go!  Authentic and old school all the way.  Very solid.  And we've always had amazing service.  One of the waiters even offered to meet up with us in Italy on our honeymoon!  Great place.  I just wish they had a wider variety of fresh pasta selections.
author: Genevieve B.

description: Golden Mirror is one of those places that i always walked by, but never thought of going in. that was until some friends who live next door to the restaurant suggested we go there for an early dinner. the interior is that of an old school fancy Italian restaurant, charming and comforting. i really liked the feel of the bar. it was very classic in design, and what? yes i would love some complimentary ritz crackers with cheese with my wine! yes, i would love some freshly garlic bread! apparently, you need to ask for the garlic bread, but it's worth it. it seems as if everyone in our party ordered a pasta dish, which i had no complaints. the pasta was cooked to perfection, and each dish came out piping hot (we were a party of 6). they even accommodated one of our friends for a vegetarian pasta dish. all in all, solid service, solid food, and a hidden gem in the sunset.
author: Rebecca Q.

description:
The decor is more like the set from a cheap theater guild than authentic.  

The service was really good...  

The food was C- at best.  With all the Italian available in the city, this place is not worth a second visit by me.
author: Johnny C.

description: This is a very nice local restaurant in the inner sunset. Old decoration, castle style make s it unique. I went there for dinner, and really enjoy myself. The food was good, but I for some reason I didn't taste anything that drove me crazy and make me want to comeback. I order a lazanha, very good pasta and sauce, but definitly a small portion for a $ 15 bucks lazanha. Thats the only reason why I only give 4 stars for the Gold MIrror, little overprice for the portions. When I realize my green salad for one person was $ 11 dollars. I love to comeback there but only if I found someone to pay my bill next time.
author: Alex M.

description:
Nice little Italian place, with really great, attentive service, and solid food. 

The waiters definitely take pride in the food they serve--we ordered the prosciutto and melon, and the waiter made a little face and said that he thought that the melon might be too young. a minute later he came out and said that the melon was "no good" and he could do prosciutto and mozzarella instead. maybe some people wouldn't like that, but i prefer mozzarella over melon anyway, and i appreciated him looking out for our table instead of serving us what he considered faulty food. 

for the main meal we ordered veal piccata and petrale meuniere, which were both solid choices. i'm pretty sure all of the meals come with the same sides of yellow rice and one kind of vegetable. again, maybe some people would not be into the side dishes, but i usually don't eat most of my side dishes anyway, so it's not a big concern to me if i don't get a lot of options on what they are. the portions are pretty reasonable--you will leave full, but they aren't so big that you leave feeling sick from forcing in too much food. 

decor is heavy on the tacky we want to make SURE you know you are in an italian restuarant side, but i'm kind of into tacky. i found it quaint. if you are looking for a hip, trendy place, go somewhere else, but if you are looking for something cozy for a date, or just someplace where you can comfortably talk to your dining companion, this is a good choice.
author: Mary Beth D.

description: great place for a classic italian dinner. highly recommend it to those who love italian food. just moved to SF and I now know where I will be going for italian food. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Ps try the teiramisu. unreal.
author: Chris F.

description: Dined here last night. Food was AMAZING! Hard to compare it to anything I've tasted outside of Italy. Our party had: Cannelloni so light it almost floated off the plate, Rib steak smothered with mushrooms, Halibut excellent, ravioli - another fabulously wonderful pasta in the most tasty sauce.. the kind you start wanting the recipe. then we had the Italian creme cake... to die for!  We were told ingredients are as fresh local and organic. Also great is they are open until 10.  we are late diners and this was just a fabulous dining experience! Thanks to Chefs Dom and Roberto for such an awesome place to dine right here on our side of the city.
author: N G.

description: Good old school Italian food at reasonable prices.  The Cannelloni and Ravioli are stars here.  Salads are pretty good.  A reliable neighborhood restaurant - I kinda like that it doesn't attract the trendy crowd from the other side of town.
author: Al K.

description: The food is okay, but the prices are pretty outrageous, relatively speaking.  Nice old style restaurant, but for the simple dishes they serve and feature, I don't see this as a regular place  for me.  I would rather brave the crowds at Westlake Joe's
author: Glenn L.

description: Went there during the holidays with some buddies. First of all, the female bartender was a real pro. Knew how to make a perfect Martini. After talking with her, she had over 30 yrs. bartending. Plus like me, she is a SF native. I ordered an appetizer which was the baked tripe. Man that was good. The tripe marinating in the garlic tomato sauce was tender as hell. My main course was the chicken picatta. It was delicious. Good portions of tender chicken, not overly lemonated. Served with pasta and sauteed vegs. I grew up in the sunset but now live in San Bruno. It's good to know that I don't have to drive and grapple with parking in North Beach for good italian food.
author: Jerry T.

description: We went here for a family get together after Thankgiving. The food and service were both excellent. The ony complaint I have is in the bill. We did not realize that the tip was already added in so we actually doubled the tip. I think the waiter was overjoyed and didn't figure that we made a mistake, otherwise it was a great experience.
author: mary f.

description: Good atmosphere great food.  Halfway through dinner my friend said, "this is the best calamari steak I've ever had".  Enough said.
author: Scott S.

description:
I ended up here on the recommendation of a friend, and had a wonderful experience all around. Seriously - some of the best Italian food I've had in my 12 years living in SF.

Between the 4 of us we ordered a salad with excellent homemade blue cheese dressing so thick you could stand a fork in it, the prawns doré (enormous prawns in a light egg batter with a lemon-wine sauce), the lasagna (lovely, not the usual brick o'starch and cheese), the canneloni (like eating clouds, *amazing*), and the excellent gnocchi, which were not on the menu that night but which they made for a friend who was vegetarian. Everything we ordered was absolutely delicious.

Unlike some of the reviewers' experience, I found the food to be very well seasoned, and the service was IMPECCABLE, especially considering we were 4 dirty, sandy hipsters in hoodies and flip flops (we had come straight from a day at the beach and ended up at the Gold Mirror kind of as a fluke). They treated us as well as every other person in the place. 

The tiramisu we shared was light and delicious, not too sweet. We also shared a bottle of very reasonable red wine. It came to $44 each with tax and tip and was worth every penny.

Can't recommend this place highly enough; cant' wait to go back. It would be a great place to take the folks or for a date.
author: elgin m.

description: Celebrated my birthday here (9 guests total including me). We made reservations so didn't have a problem waiting. Fried calimari came out cold, shrimp cocktails came out with tiny salad shrimps (gross). The food was bland. The new york cut was cheap, my sister couldn't eat it, it was full of tendon. Service was awful. I had to catch a waiter, any waiter at this point to get a coke. I ask the waitress, can you refil our cokes? To which she replied we don't do refills. Um, just get us more sodas. If we're paying 25-30 bucks a plate, I think we can afford cokes, I shouldn't even have to ask you. Gratuity was added to the bill because there was more than six of us, which is fine, but we didn't leave additional because we were very dissatisfied overall.
author: Trina K.

description: Well all I can say about the Gold Mirror is it has "jumped the shark" bigtime.  This place used to be pretty good but just like most of the good old San Francisco restaurants, the owners kick it and then it goes to hell, basically.  The same can be said for Scoma's, Capps Corner, etc.  The last time I ate here I ordered sole and it was so saturated with lemon I could barely eat it.  I actually would have sent it back but was with a group of people for a birthday celebration and didn't want to make a stink about it. Not one single person in my party made any comment about the food which I think pretty much tells the story.  Needless to say, I wouldn't recommend the Gold Mirror anymore.  Too bad.  It used to be a good neighborhood spot back in the day.
author: Rabbit B.

description: Old school Italian in the best possible sense.   I had the ravioli, Amy had the utterly sublime cannelloni, and we both had the hearty minestrone.  If you're folks are  visiting from out of town, I suggest a trip to the zoo followed with dinner here.  Dishes range from $15-$22.
author: Steve G.

description: Good old-fashioned DiMaggio-era San Francisco Italian.  Waiters in tuxedos.  Mirror (well, Gold) behind the bar.  Packed at 5 pm with regulars wearing hearing aids splitting orders of veal parmigiana.  Bring mom.  Let's keep the Gold Mirror in business!
author: Michelle C.

description: We love this restaurant.  My husband would eat every meal here for the rest of his life if he could.  He discovered it not long ago because one of his friends invited him for a boys night out to watch old boxing movies while trying out the excellent food at the Gold Mirror.  We live right around the corner, and now our whole family goes at least once or twice a month.  We have small children and I never feel like we are an annoyance that the staff can't wait to get rid of!  They always make something good up for my girls to enjoy even if it isn't exactly on the menu.  The grownup food is pretty good too, and the bar looks like a pretty comfy place to sit and have a drink while doing some work.  I hear the Gold Mirror was recently rennovated ... something about a Safeway truck backing up into the front door?  Whatever it was, the decor and food are great and we love the Gold Mirror.
author: Alison L.

description:
Yup, old school Italian, and there couldn't have been a better place to hold my husband's surprise 60th birthday. The staff, on that packed Saturday night, made us feel like we were the only party there. The waiter was always available and really saw to our every need. The matriarch of the restaurant held a great deadpan face as we went into the restaurant, asking for a small table, never revealing the party that awaited my husband.

They even printed up a lovely menu (commemorating my husband's birthday) including choice of salad and five entrees to choose from.

Now on to the food. We started with an antipasti tray including very fresh salumi, cheese, peppers and olives. Also passed around were orders of fried calamari. I'd forgotten this style of calamari. It is flour dredged and quickly sauteed in garlic. Yum!

We added more garlic bread to the mix and chose between romaine hearts with blue cheese dressing--very freshly and expertly executed or caesar salad, which even came with an anchovy.

Entrees choices for our large party: fettucine alfredo, lasagne, spaghetti/meatballs, veal piccata, petrale.

That's where it fell into "acceptable" category. Each dish came out plated  and prepared very well . Flavor was nice, but not exceptional. Didn't matter, though. The service and hospitality of this restaurant more than made up for some missing flavors.

I made a gigantic cake that the waiter deftly cut and served. In addition to wine, we also served champagne, and the staff was right there, with champagne flues.  They also let us linger, almost closing the place down that night. I can't say enough about how wonderful this restaurant is. Old style. Family style. I love it!
author: louise f.

description: I was there with friends within the last few months. The food was excellent but it was way too pricey for what we got.  We ordered appetizers, entrees and desserts shared among us.  The bill came with a lump sum for our food orders and amounted to about $70 per person (NOT including wines, beverages, taxes or tips yet!).  I was surprised that the restaurant did not itemize the bill for the entrees, appetizers or desserts and just wrote whatever lump sum they wanted to their liking for our group.  Nobody wanted to make a fuss of that as we were in a large group sharing the bill, but in retrospect, it wasn't right that specific charges were not disclosed as they should have been in any restaurant bill.  This doesn't give an impression of honesty which would make me or our group want to go back.  I give them two stars because all the food was delicious but the appetizers, entrees and desserts we had really should have cost up to $50 per person.
author: Linda A.

description:
Ah the Gold Mirror, what can one say? The main entrees (meat dishes) are to die for. Always cooked perfectly, great taste, plenty of food, very well done. I crave their fillet Mignon medallions wrapped in bacon! 

The pasta.... eh. Not the greatest, don't get me wrong. But not the greatest. 

They have a good wine selection with a couple really good Italian wines, and the atmosphere is homey and worth while. 

The service is usually pretty good. It can get a little slow at times. Everyone is very friendly at all times, just not always on point. Relaxed is the term I would apply to it. 

All that being said, I love going there. It is not too expensive, the food is worth the money you pay, and you always feel welcome and at home. I would try it if you haven't yet.
author: Katie C.

description:
I typically only write reviews which i feel strongly about, and i normally only write reviews for restaurants which i feel deserve a 4 to 5 stars but I feel the need to warn other yelpers about this place so they wont make the same mistake i did.

I decided to host a birthday dinner here after reading the reviews on citysearch.  At the time, gold mirror had a rating of 8.9 or 9.1, i forget which.  I cant stress enough how bad the food is.  The chicken is extremely dry, everything is bland and there was nothing special about it.  School cafeteria food taste better than this, and thats not an exaggeration!  It wasnt just me who complained about the food, it was everyone at the party.  Portions were also small.  Ok, I dont mind if the portions were small if the food actually taste good.  They also charged a whooping 25% gratuity on top of another $25 for a cake cutting fee.  The service was also horrible.  Everyone paid double, and some even paid triple than what they were supposed to pay.  My order was no more than $20, but I ended up paying $75 for disgusting food that was not even filling.  This was the worst experience I ever had, nothing even came close!  Dont waste your time and money.  Take your money to McDonalds, you'll have a better experience, better food and you'll be saving yourself tons of money!
author: Damon J.

description: Half-assed website. Followed by an overcharge on our food. Followed by a rude response to my inquiry about why we were overcharged. Followed by me walking out angry. Followed by lackluster food, and tiny portions. Bummer.
author: David H.

description: We tried the calamari steak and the stuffed shrimp.  The first taste was not bad.  As you're eating into half the meal, you just realized that the first impression did not last.  The food gets more bland.  I have no idea how that happens.  The calamari steak just gets chewy and the shrimp loses its juicyness.  I don't think I will be back.  Once was enough.
author: AhLin C.

description:
my friend had her birthday dinner here. personally,  i like pasta p more. i had the seafood pasta and it came with bok choy.. yes bok choy??? i never knew italians ate bok choy! my plate was rather bland. 

we had the entire upstairs, which was up to top of the kitchen. we were all sweating as we  were eatting. so don't get the any table upstair. it gets really hot up there. 

its prolly a ok place considering you're in sunset searching for italian food, avoiding the craziness of north beach. but if u want great italian food go to north beach.
author: Jules D.

description:
calamari...soggy and burnt

food...bland

service...great!
author: Mai G.

description: Coming from Marin to meet friends from the South Bay,  a San Francisco native recommended Gold Mirror as a good midpoint with good food. The food was indeed very good...everything the 4 of us ordered, no duplications, was  delicious. The service was a little sporadic but we chalked that up to it being a busy Saturday evening. The tiramisu was just average, I wouldn't waste the calories again on that,  but the artichoke special appetizer was one I'd order again. Lots of garlic but it didn't linger. I had petrole sole Dore, and when we  go back I  hope they have it  again (also a special that night) One dinner companion had the eggplant Parm, which to him is comfort food, and he pronounced it excellent. This is  now  one of our favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Alice W.

description: A good old-fashioned Italian restaurant. Can be pricy if you're on a budget.
author: D'Andy C.

description: If you are looking for a cute family owned, old-school italian restaurant, Gold Mirror is for you. I have eaten here twice and was not disappointed either time! Their menu is pretty basic, they have a small selection of pasta and appetizers, however, they have a huge selection of meat entrees. They have a lot of different options for free range chicken dishes, veal, steak, and seafood! The meat dishes come with rice and vegetables. I've only had their pasta here, which was really good! I recommend the spaghetti with clams. But next time I want to try the seafood! Their dessert selection is also really good! I recommend the cheesecake with chocolate and raspberry sauce and/or the spumoni!  The wine selection is also very extensive and they have a fully stocked bar that can make most cocktails. The servers are also very friendly and attentive. My water was never empty and empty dishes were not left out on our table for long. Also the servers came by quite frequently to make sure everything was ok, even though, they were busy!
author: Mai L.

description: My boyfriend LOVES the calamari - he says it is the best he has ever had bc it is not deep fried and rubbery.  The canaloni is lovely as well - really tasty.  I really have no complaints about this place.  Oh, and the people who said that it was too expensive are nuts.  This is a good moderately priced Italian place with a good wine selection and quality food.
author: samantha D.

description: i swear i've overheard some mob meetings here. awesome italian...in the sunset of all places. they make the best lasagne i've ever had: super thin layers of pasta with bechamel sauce and sausage...baked on a per order basis (not like most places that make a huge tray of lasagne and give you a slice). truly awesome. the baked calamari is something special too...as is the old-school ritz crackers and cheeseball you'll find at the bar--but get there early for that one...it goes fast. has a real "family owned" feel to it...and the thick italian accents on the servers add to the authenticity. as for the decor...bizarre...but not enough to take away any of the 5 stars i'm giving gold mirror.
author: dusty d.

description: This is my favorite old-school Italian restaurant in SF.  It is at least as good as any of the places in North Beach.  They were closed for about a year after a truck smashed into the building and destroyed the place, but now it's better than ever.  It isn't on the menu anymore, but you can still order a chicken liver entree.  For lover's of this dish, this is the place to go.  They have an excellent Ceasar with their own slightly different take on it.  Those looking for yupscale new-age fusion Italian food should look elsewhere.  This is a place Tony Soprano would love.
author: Anonymou S.

description: This place is hilarious! Love the kitschy "Roman" decorations. There's an old-school Italian charm to it - the kind of place you'd take your grandma for Sunday dinner. The food was fairly decent - I got the bolognese with gigantic meatballs, which were incredible tender and moist. But, I'm always a little wary of Italian places that serve butter with their bread, but eh, I'll overlook it. I don't know that I'd come back often (prices seem a bit inflated), but when I have a hankering for giant meatballs, I'll definitely come here.
author: Lemon S.

description: I grew up in San Francisco in the 1950's -  living quite near the Gold Mirror when they first opened in their 18th and Taraval location;  and I can remember eating there for "prom" nights nearly 50 years ago!  I have always enjoyed it, and although I have lived in Walnut Creek for many years I occasionally return to the old neighborhood for a meal at the Gold Mirror, which has been operated by the same family for generations.  My brother, who now lives in Washington State, was in town working the Fancy Food Show and we decided to go there as he too had fond memories of it.  This place is true to its core - a real unpretentious San Francisco Italian restaurant that serves traditional and plentiful food at a fair price.  The very retro dining room and bar is comfortable and clean.  The wait staff - all dressed in well-worn tuxedos is attentive and clearly under the watchful eye of Mama Gold Mirror who circulates through the dining room insuring everything is running according to her wishes.   We made a reservation by phone (I do not think they take them on-line) and our table was available when we arrived.  My wife joined us so there were three of us for dinner.  We decided to take our time and enjoy a drink at our table before ordering and although the restaurant was filling fast (every table was full by the time we ordered) we were not pressured to turn-the-table.  We shared fried calamari with garlic to start and it was very tasty.  I ordered Veal Parmesan and I think the recipe was the one they used 50 years ago.  If you are interested in a light, low-calorie, low-fat meal, do not order this dish.  On the other hand, I knew what I was getting into - the Veal was done right and I enjoyed it.  My brother (who is quite a foodie) went for the Lasagna and he thought it was excellent; in fact after eating at three other rather upscale San Francisco restaurants that week, he told me that the meal at the Gold Mirror was the best of the bunch.  I will be back in the old neighborhood and will eat at the Gold Mirror again.  I hope it never changes - they do not make them like this any more.
author: David P.

description: Well, the space is nice, and it has some old world charm.  The bartender was nice, and I felt like this just might be a warm, inviting place to go to pretty often. But then, the experience that we had with our waiter was really poor. Distilled down to one word, it'd have to be 'disrespectful'. When he asked if we had any questions about the wine list and I responded that we'd probably just choose among the wines by the glass, he turned away without another word and walked off. He didn't tell us the specials of the night until we'd already been seated for fifteen minutes. The second I finished giving him the food order, he turned around and left, even though I had the wine list open in front of me. He paid attention to seemingly all of his other tables while we sat there waiting for our check for another fifteen minutes. He was not gracious, not personable, and seemed to only do the very minimum required. I can't help but think that if we had another waiter, our overall dining experience might have been much better. We might go back, but no time soon. Too many other places to go where you don't have to put up with that kind of behavior. The food, for what it's worth, was middle-of-the-road (including the cannelloni).

description: My yuppie friends call me and say, "hey we're going to so and so's B-day dinner" I say, "I'm there". When I got there I was confused. The restaurant says, "I'm an old-timer Italian restaurant." There are strange red plastic lighting around the bar, from some some long ago revamp. There are gaudy chandeliers, and yes some 2/3D stagecoach on the wall with a picture of a man (chef?) standing inside. The evident wine selection denotes class and sophistication. What really  infers a "good-old Italian place" are the wait staff with actual Tuxedos! With all that I expected Mom-quality food. Alas I was disappointed. I got Minestrone and Veal Parmesan. Minestrone was good, but nothing to write home about. The Veal was soft and the flavor was well balanced, yet kinda bland. I think I expected the food to match the environment. It does not. It's obvious that this place has been here a while, and judging from the food:  times change.
author: Redd J.

description: I had lunch here the other day, very good, classic, old school Italian.  I had the special gnoochi Sorentina.  They are homemade and SOOO good, the way gnoochi should be- light and tasty, not chewy or heavy like store bought or frozen.  The service was great and the warm french bread, so good, I ate the whole basket-full.  The food is classic, fresh and healthy.  Come here to get full, but not for surprises.  If you like snobby food, this is not the place for you.  This is a classic place and there are few left like it!   A great spot to take your parents or an aunt, that sort of place.
author: Anna Z.

description: Been going to the Gold Mirror for over 35 years, and in all those times I have never had a bad meal.  The DeGrande family has been there all those years, and although Guiseppe has retired (although he still comes back to help out once in a while), his sons Dominic and Roberto carry on in the family tradition.  The menu has been only slightly modified from years past, but only for the better.  We have had just about every entree on the menu (plus the specials which are not on the menu, but the waiters describe them very well) and have our favorites, but almost any entree would be allright with us.  Lunch is served M-F, and the restaurant caters to the seniors in the area who still love the food but perhaps don't like going out at night any more.  Worth a trip to the Parkside; parking can be dicey, but you can almost always find a space.  If you long for the "old school" Italian restaurants that used to be in North Beach, the Gold Mirror is the place to go!!
